Snorkeling at Pigeon Island is an amazing experience with crystal-clear waters, colorful corals, and plenty of marine life, including reef sharks and vibrant fish. It‚Äôs one of the best activities in Sri Lanka for beginners and nature lovers looking for a memorable underwater adventure.

column8: Not worth the effort and money
column11: Don't do that. Of course, you will most likely see a turtle and a reef shark. But otherwise it is a sad underwater graveyard of dead coral, with a few fish still swimming there. Not worth it and way too expensive for what you get to see.
Under supervision the most beautiful fish, even sharks and turtles seen. Tip apply sunscreen or wear a shirt. You'll burn like hell.

column8: Sad image of a destroyed paradise ‚Äì urgent protection needed!
column11: I was full of anticipation for the visit to Pigeon Island ‚Äì all the greater was my disappointment, sadness and anger when I saw how incredibly large the coral reef has already been destroyed. In my opinion, entering the island should be prohibited immediately. There would certainly be ways to make snorkeling here much more environmentally friendly ‚Äì for example, by letting visitors swim in the water from the boat to the beautiful spots instead of letting them off on land. Compulsory life jackets could also help tourists to avoid touching or accidentally damaging sensitive corals. I don't understand how to exploit such a unique treasure for money at such short notice rather than protecting it sustainably. Of course, I am aware that the population in Sri Lanka is very poor in many places ‚Äì but that is precisely why this wealth of nature should be preserved in the long term, rather than irretrievably destroyed by mass rush and lack of rules. It's bitter to see one of the most beautiful places I've ever wanted to experience being so doomed.

column8: Consider carefully whether you want this
column11: You think you're going to a protected area, partly because of the high entrance fee, but there's not much left to protect. Besides some nice fish and a turtle, you mainly see other tourists and dead coral. In retrospect, we should have taken the alternative offer and gone to Angel rock. This would have saved a lot of money (about ‚Ç¨40 pp) and probably annoyance and frustration.

column8: Mass event in the national park
column11: It's quite violent the masses of people being brought to this spot. One wonders what will be done with the 40‚Ç¨/person entrance fee for the national park. Shouldn't this be meant to protect this sensitive zone? Many people stand on the corals, many are already broken. There seems to be no awareness of conservation. The underwater world is still very beautiful, it was an experience for the children. But from a conservation point of view, we can't really recommend this. In my opinion, a visitor quota should be considered and trained rangers should pay attention to what is happening here.

Tourists are occasionally dropped on Pigeon Island. Then they have to go snorkelling under the ‚Äòguidance‚Äô of a guide and ready again. The result is that a relentless stream of people snorkel the same round. The result is that groups swim right through each other, which means that the overview is lost. Our guide had no idea how many people he had in his group. He did count along the way, but if you don't know what you're counting then it all gets very tricky. Two children were missing afterwards. One reported himself the second took a very long time. And besides the supervisors being busy shouting at each other, not much action was taken. Besides this, don't think when you come here that you can snorkel at your own pace in a spot of your own choosing. Save you the money (we paid US$70 pp) and effort. I'm sure there are cheaper, prettier and more laid-back alternatives nearby.

Very chaotic since the early hours of the morning. We swam accompanied by a very nice guy who showed us turtles, starfish, colorful fish and sharks. The corals are all gray. Snorkeling starts from the beach of pigeon‚Äôs island not from the reef. I honestly expected better.

column8: As bad as they say, but you‚Äôre supporting the economy, I guess‚Ä¶.
column11: We went, with our eyes fully open having read the negative reviews here. It was as bad as everyone said: dead reef; cloudy visibility; tourist soup. Oh yes, and hugely expensive. The main upside is that by going, you‚Äôre doing something to support the regeneration of the economy here after the natural and man-made tragedies that have befallen the place in the last 20 or so years. We did see a turtle and a reef shark amongst the flippers and life jackets, I should add.

It was an enjoyable visit - we saw reef sharks and a turtle and plenty of fish.  The tour company we used was good with a nice guide who paid special attention to our 11 year old child. It is expensive but I believe most of the fees are national park fees - at least I hope that‚Äôs the case! On the negative side, the coral in the shallow area around the island is mostly dead and there were far too many people there at the same time. It is clearly suffering from over tourism which by visiting it ourselves we know we are contributing to. Therefore mixed feelings about going as not sure what will be left at pigeon island in a few years if tourism continues there at the current rate. Hopefully the locals have a plan to conserve the site for future generations to enjoy.

what a rip off.. they wanted to charge me 25.000 LKR (75$) just for the ticked fee (2adults +6 yo kid)  to enter pigeon island because it is a natural park. Apart from this you still need to pay the boat, snorkel...to the company organizing the tour. Btw, from people I know that dived here in the past, the coral there is almost dead since 2023 or so
Disappointing. Many boats with many people who go there every day. Saw three turtles, though. You'll get dropped off pretty good if you're not careful.

Pros and cons‚Ä¶ please see both. üòâ Very nice island worth visiting. 1-2h - especially for kids as it has a Robinson Crusoe feel to it. Snorkeling: Corals are almost all dead but many sea-turtles and black-tip reef shark. However, the snorkeling gear provided is exceptionally poor and almost completely ruining the experience. I very much recommend renting snorkeling gear from one of the proper dive centers (e.g. Pearl dive center) or at the very minimum, asking to see and fit snorkeling gear prior to departing/paying. Snorkles were the kind you buy for children in a toy-store. Mask was too little for me and no soap provided, so besides taking in water, it quickly got foggy. My daughters snorkle took in water and at least for her, the snorkeling was pointless despite sharks and turtles. Earlier same day, we had excellent snorkeling trip with Pearl Divers but they don‚Äôt have access to Pigeon Island. Note fairly high prices due to special admission fee for national park. Just prior to closing time (17:00) my daughter had the great/fun experience of walking in shallow water opposite side of snorkeling and 2 baby sharks came swimming by. This made the entire trip worth it.
We did a snorkelling trip from Uppaveli beach and saw turtles and sharks. Quite busy but an amazing morning. They charge like a wounded bull for park entry‚Ä¶

If you have experience with snorkeling or diving you will be disappointed.  It's true that you can see some colorful fish and some turtles but the environment is in a bad state: dead corals, due to the trampling of the many tourists. Given the very high cost, it's not worth it.  If you have no experience in this field and want to see some colorful fish, and you have 75 euros each to spend, instead, you can decide to go.  Anyway, it's the typical golden-egg pigeon...

I thought it was terrible. All that dead coral on the beach and in the sea. So-called protected nature reserve but it was teeming with tourists who just stand on the coral because they don't know any better. Yes we have seen sea turtles, sharks and beautiful fish but the sadness of how bad our sea is prevailed with me.
Really enjoyed the snorkelling at Pigeon Island - we spotted many reef sharks and a couple of turtles on one side, on the other we saw some baby sharks and great range of fish. Definitely worthwhile.
Waste of money for ¬£50, such a scam from the government charging 13,000lkr to foreigners for an okay experience. Would recommend snorkelling elsewhere.

We corroborate in 2025 what bcp French have already written for some for many years (we are stupid not to have followed their advice). The site is overcrowded, corals are getting sicker or dead, fish are rare compared to other sites where we could swim, we could see just from a distance a shark and loan a turtle. The sea was rough, the water quite cloudy. A whole commercial system around boats and equipment that ultimately costs very much compared to the Service rendered. We do not recommend at all.
Beautiful snorkeling experience we saw at least 3 turtles and some reef sharks as well as various colorful fish and a beautiful coral reef

Pigeon Island is one of the most beautiful places we visited in Sri Lanka. The sea is incredibly crystal clear and the reef, despite being partly damaged, is still home to lots of colorful fish, turtles and sometimes even small blackfin sharks (absolutely harmless!). Snorkeling here was an unforgettable experience: clear water, fascinating seabed and the feeling of being immersed in a natural aquarium. The island itself is small but very scenic, with rocks, white sand and a wild atmosphere. Highly recommended for lovers of the sea and nature. Bring with you mask, snorkel and respect for this wonderful place!
I arrived without having lunch and they made me a quick lunch!! Super nice! I would have expected them to make me pay and instead no, offered by their kindness!!

Such a huge variety of fish and other underwater animals. I would even give a guarantee, according to our experience, that you will encounter sharks and turtles. But don‚Äôt worry the sharks are rather shy and the turtles let you within a few inches of being filmed. A must on a Sri Lankan holiday in the north-east!
Very colorless, pretty broken reef. If you've been to Egypt or something, you don't need to go here. We've seen turtles and sharks but that didn't rip it out. And then 40 euros admission......

The water was clear and I saw plenty of beautiful fish and interesting corals. However it only needed 30 minutes to see everything so including the boat ride the trip should be advertised as 1 hour and not 2, and therefore should also be cheaper.
Beautiful reef and lots to see. Good alternative to Pigeon Island. The guides could have been a bit more communicative, but they were always friendly.
It‚Äôs not that nice . The island ticket officer is so rude. They are charging for so many things once you enter to the island. The corals are dead not that nice tbh. Waste of our time .

Pigeon Island in Trincomalee is a must-visit. The pristine beaches, clear waters, and vibrant coral reefs make it perfect for swimming and snorkeling. The island's natural beauty and rich marine life are truly captivating. Don't miss the chance to experience whale and dolphin watching!

Loved our experience at Pigeon Island. We went on a weekday and it was off season so there was not much of a crowd. We hired a guide, Fahard who was amazing and he took us to snorkeling. Highly recommend to take a guide as he knows all the spots to see turtles and sharks. We swam with turtles and sharks and it was absolutely amazing. Highly recommend.

Expensive to enter the National park but worth the money. Saw 20+massive reef sharks and numerous turtles. Our guide with Aqua Dreams (on the beach near to Fernando's) was excellent and it felt very safe. I'm an anxious snorkeler when in shallow reef and so was provided with buoyancy aide and well looked after.

Personally I didn‚Äôt really get it, yes it‚Äôs a cool island with some cool snorkelling to do, but I didn‚Äôt feel it was worth the $60 ticket price. Note there are zero facilities on the island so take whatever you need if you plan on being there a while!

We went snorkelling here and we were debating whether to do this because of the price of the National Park entrance fee and we are a family of 5.  There are other places you can go to like Coral Island without the fee.  However, we swam with 6 sharks and a turtle plus all the other colourful fish and it was amazing.  It was very crowded and perhaps it would have been just as good snorkelling elsewhere but for what we saw, I am so happy we went. Our hotel organised it through "Kingfisher Snorkelling and Whale Watching" who are located on the beach, so you could go direct, and they supplied all the equipment including optical masks for my husband and son who have bad eyesight.

Beautiful place to snorkel, they take you by boat , and leave you in beach area , what is beautiful is its seabed on both sides of the island, but I find abusive prices for tourists, like most activities in Sri Lanka, I recommend going early since afterwards it is a pilgrimage where you barely have room to go out or enter the water

I personally wouldn't bother with Pigeon Island. The entry fee and cost of getting there is not worth it for sub standard snorkeling. The visibility was poor, there's a few fish around bit nothing amazing. Saw one turtle and one reef shark. Save your money and try something else!

Tricky one. I wanted to love it. Went with our 4 kids ages 16,13,10,10. It absolutely is not suitable for 10 year olds. The snorkelling on the near side of the island is rough and deep and not safe for young kids. Our guide did not inform us it was deep snorkelling with really strong swimming skills needed. We stopped after 5 mins to get life jackets for the 10 year olds but it was too tough for them. So they headed back with my wife. I continued with my older 2. We did see sharks and amazing fish. There are far too many people there. Our guide actually lost us meaning we ended up being washed up on shallow coral which was obviously awful for the coral. I think I‚Äôd have loved it if there had been half the number of people, had been half the price and we‚Äôd had a better guide and we didn‚Äôt have young children. Miss it if you have younger kids.

Very nice trip to Pigeon Island. Staff were very professional and helpful. There is brand new snorkeling equipment, including oversized fins (my son is a size 48). When snorkeling we booked a guide (1,000 Rs. Per person). Worth it! He knows the best spots on the reef. We saw a shark and a water turtle and fish of all colors). üëçüëçüëç

It's a marine park, where you can see all sorts of marine life in Sri Lanka. It is safe and educational for the kids where they can interact and explore within safe coral barriers. For more experienced snorkeling enthusiasts have the open ocean area where marked by floating buoys and lines.

Awesome snorkeling site, highly recommended. We stayed at nilaveli beach and arranged the tour by walking in on one of the local dive shops (Ceylon divers), despite the lower price (48.000 srl for 3 persons), and can totally recommend it. The site is quite busy, and the water was best early, so recommend going there quite early (we went from 9-12 ish) Saw 8-10 reef sharks, 1 turtle and loads of beautiful fish.

WARNING! Please refer to the government set (gazetted) price list when purchasing entrance tickets to Pigeon Island from the counter in Nilaveli Beach. The person there uses multiple receipt books and quotes multiple times the actual price literally stealing from tourist. We were quoted 15000 rupees per person when the actual price should be approx 9000 per person. He had also quoted another British couple staying at Nilaveli a whopping 300 British pounds! We obviously decided not to proceed with the tour when we heard the price and only found out that he was trying to rip us off after doing research for hours and calling Tourism development authority and tourism police. His response when I confronted him much later ‚Äúwho are you to enquire so much‚Äù ‚Äú9000 and 15000 is very similar‚Äù. I couldn‚Äôt believe it!!! Disappointing that we missed out due to this greedy thief!

We traveled from Pasikuda, in a tuk tuk with a group of 9 people. The boat cost 16,000 rupees per person (organizers‚Äô equipment, they also provide free lunch) underwater there are gardens of colorful corals, sharks, fish, turtles. Remember for life

Pigeon Island turned out to be an unexpected delight during our visit to Trincomalee in March 2024. While I initially hesitated, preferring to head straight to the hotel for some relaxation, my wife's insistence led us to this gem of an experience. The government's setup at Nilaveli Beach streamlined the boat and snorkeling adventure seamlessly. Although I hadn't planned on snorkeling, I'm grateful we did. It proved to be an exhilarating adventure, with an abundance of reef sharks and stunning coral formations. I'd recommend bringing your own snorkeling equipment for added convenience and hygiene. March seems to be an ideal time to visit, as it's less crowded compared to the peak season. Overall, Pigeon Island exceeded my expectations, offering a perfect blend of adventure and natural beauty.

Beautiful island for snorkelling but sadly no facilities on the island. As couple of hours was enough for us. It‚Äôs quite expensive for the boat and entrance fee. If you want to go longer, take food and water. Probably better areas to see!

I paid about $80, this included entrance fee , guide and bost ride there and back . You can stay as long as you want. I definitely recommend a guide, he'll show you the best spots. I saw about 8 black tip sharks ,2 turtles and many coral and vivid colored fish. I used my new underwater camera and was pleased at what I saw. A very small area so not  else to see.  I had 2 45 min sessions

Don't go there off-season. Although it was end of march, and the season was just couple of  weeks away. It was a scary and long journey to the island maneuvering among the waves. Saw two sharks, otherwise you could see all the same for much lesser amount of money in other places. Might have had a better experience if the visit was during the season

Since we couldn‚Äôt go scuba diving, we went snorkling on pigeon island. The boat was arranged by our hotel (Nilaveli beach hotel) and the arranged mask&tuba and fins. We went in the afternoon. Therefore the sea was a little rougher, and the visibility was less. However, we saw a turtle and two blacktip reefsharks.

immediately after a confirmed booking I  got a whatsapp with a time change,  they did not run the boat that was confirmed. Also clear instruction "do  not book on Tripadvisor" Snorkling partly ok, reef dead, some fish, couple turtles and a shark. Second part of the snorkling  in very low  visibility water, the guide decided to send the crowd in alone. If someone was  not a good swimmer, too me it looked very risky. I can only say, don't go

Another of the many things I wanted to mention about this trip, and this country, keep in mind one very important thing, in most of the paid excursions, temples and places to visit, they are going to put your eyes out, while The locals pay a pittance, the tourists' pockets are bleeding, with super outrageous prices... The island park doesn't mean anything to me at all, an excursion to spend some time and little else, it's not worth visiting at all, you You stay on the beach of the hotel you are in and that's it... a big waste of time and money... DO NOT go...... Stay on the beach in your town.....

Price absolutely disproportionate to the experience. We paid 60 euros each for just 2 hours of snorkeling. We saw sharks and a turtle, beautiful water but in every other part of the world we have been such an experience costs a third of what we spent
One of guides took u der the sea and pull off life jackets purpisefully and touched chest while sufficating.. Its not safe for girls at all. Guide name Wassim

The reef is not so big and cannot be compared with some Egyptian reefs, there are no colourful corals and not so much fish. But there are lots of turtles and sharks, we saw both and it seems that everyone does. Biggest part of the reef is a protected area and people are not supposed to be there. But local guides encourage tourists to enter, as most of the fish is there.

Spectacular Marine Park in the Nilaveli area. You can see turtles, reef sharks, cuttlefish, glopus fish, parrot fish, corals and a great diversity of tropical fish, etc. Highly recommended for all types of people, it is not necessary to be an expert in snorkeling to enjoy the dives and be able to see an amazing underwater world. There are areas where it seems like you are inside a fish tank. The entrance fee to the park varies in price depending on the influx of public and the weather on the day you want to visit. We pay ‚Ç¨40 per person plus the boat you need to get to the island, the price varies between ‚Ç¨100-200 for a boat with a maximum capacity of 6-8 people, depending. of the distance at which you are and the haggling you do before renting the boat. For the entrance to the park there is no haggling that is worth it. We pay ‚Ç¨140 for the reservation of the boat. It is highly recommended to visit it although the price of the excursion For a family of 4-5 people it can be more than ‚Ç¨300-400 per family

There are 2 sides for snorkeling. On one side you can see sharks and turtles, on the other side fish. Very expensive and many corals have already been destroyed by tourism. The side with sharks is worth it - get here early. By midday there are far too many people for the small island. It was nice but when you see what people have already done, I wouldn't go twice
Amazing experience. Snorkeling with turtles and exotic fish. Our guide ensured we didn't miss out despite my fear of the ocean. Exhilarating to say the least!

Mix review. Our driver got someone to meet us before the beach and said he will sort it all, got charged 48,000Lrk for two people with snorkeling gear, Boat to island and entrance fee. I'm not sure if this was a scam from the island or just our driver but I was upset cause it felt like we had no option. At breakfast we had been offered 36,000lrk so we knew it was more. Looking online it seems alot cheaper but also heard some places reject online bookings and you pay again. Beach we left from was beautiful. Boat to island was safe, gave us life jackets and super fast. Island it self was small but we went early to avoid crowds 9am Got offered a swiming guide for 1400 from the boat driver to show us the sharks and turtles but after how much we already spent we didn't want to spend more, should of been included. Cause we are good at snorkeling/ diving we didn't need it. Walked away from the main swimming entrance down the beach more and entered and saw Reef sharks within 1min. I was nervous but if you relax and don't splash and just go charming they don't care about you. No information was given so I understand how some people gets chased. Saw 8+ Reef sharks. Coral slowing growing back but alot dead. Swam around and on way back we saw 2 turtles eating at the bottom broken coral, but then the tourist crowds came, some were diving to touch them which I disagree with. After seeing what we wanted to see we got out of there within an hour so very expensive 240NZD for 2 for an hour. But my partner hadn't seen turtles or sharks so it was great to tick that off otherwise it would of been a let down. Lovely view on the island but no where to relax.

The place itself is very nice. The equipment that the boatmen rent is not very worn. But extremely expensive for what it offers, the coral reef is almost all dead, the fish are there but I didn't see any sharks or turtles. For the same price you can visit a national park in inland and see the elephants.

We went there early in the morning but (as is often the case here) it was a little windy (and waves) so the water was cloudy. Not ideal for snorkelling. We were not able to see any sharks in this murky water. Later in the day the wind tended to calm down, so maybe it would have been better. We saw a turtle, motionless at the bottom of the water, perhaps paralyzed by the 30 people stationed just above it to observe it. I did not feel very comfortable participating in this crowd in this small space where the shallow coral is constantly broken by the fins.

Excellent snorkelling location, reached by a quick boat ride from Nilaveli Beach Take everything you need with you as it has no cafe or shop Don‚Äôt underestimate how long you want to spend there (the boatmen return to collect you at your prearranged time) We saw a multitude of fish species, beautiful coral gardens and lots of reef sharks and three turtles
Little organized and without explaining anything to you. Neither what you are going to see, nor the best area to snorkel. They release you on the island and pick you up in three hours. End

Excursion at 2 p.m. by calm sea and splendid weather: almost no people on Pigeon Island and the presence of a caring guide who drags behind him a buoy for the children who can get tired because it lasts 2 hours. On the program, magnificent fish, turtles and sharks! A wonderful memory. Thanks Poseidon!

Pigeon Island is surrounded by an underwater paradise, which unfortunately suffers from heavy tourist use. Two snorkeling zones are easily accessible. In the southwest of the big island you can see sea turtles and reef sharks, in the north many tropical reef fish. Since the sea can also be a bit undulating, be sure to bring snorkel with blow-out valve!

Don't touch it!! Mafia structures at the ticket counter!!! We would have liked to go to the island but at the ticket counter there is a kind of mafia fighting for monopoly position and not letting smaller, independent entrepreneurs go. We, 2 women, were surrounded by 10-15 unkempt men who stood in front of the boat to prevent it from being let into the water - of course only after the entrance fee (25000 lkr) was paid. There was a wipe in your nose that you alone had the right to offer tours to the island. According to our very nice instructor, the parties are probably fighting in court right now but at present the verdict is not final. So far, everyone should still offer these tours. We were asked to get on another boat, which could drive us. But what woman does that to a horde of men who just called you names...?! Police and authorities only said ‚Äúclarify it yourself.‚Äù And in the end there was not even the money back ‚Äúno refund but you can go on another boat‚Äù. But again, what woman does that after being approached like that before? No... end of the song: the instructor had to pay the money back out of his own pocket. At least that's what we have again - but the day has gone by after such an experience. I therefore unfortunately advise against making this trip - at least until the situation is clarified who now has the right one to make this trip!!!

Great experience!!! We had the chance to swim with sharks and a turtle (in the morning there were even schools of sharks and several turtles but we arrived a little late)!!! On the other hand small advice, the trip to Pigeon Island being a little excessive financially we followed the advice of our driver who directed us to fishermen pretending to make the same trip but for half the fare ... Big strategic error, because we certainly saw very nice fish but neither sharks nor turtles that a priori really stay around close to the island ... So the next day we had to redo the real exit and this time have the chance to see absolutely everything we wanted to see ... but we will have paid twice ... finally not very economic!!!

we were diving and went to Pidgeon island between dives. it was an expensive ticket at $60 for the 2 of us for 90 min snorkling. If we had not seen a turtle and followed it for 20 min and some reef sharks then i would have felt unhappy with the entrance fee. One other issue was that it would be wise not to get sick on the island as they do not have any emergency first aid - we saw a near drowning where the guy needed CPR and they had nothing, he was lucky one of the dive boats had oxygen to allow him to be eventually shipped off
we paid 16500 rupiah for 1 hour of snorkeling.  we saw neither turtles nor sharks.  it really pissed me off

Pigeon Island National Park is near the Nilaveli Beach in Sri Lanka. This National Park is amongst the 17 national parks in the country, but amongst the only two marine national parks in the entire region. This area is protected due to the aftermath of the 2004 Tsunami, which caused a lot of damage to the marine and coral life. This national park is also known to have the best coral reefs in the entire country! The rocky island is also home to rock pigeons, based on which the national park gets its name. Diving and snorkeling are two everyday activities done here, apart from safari and hike.

We made this trip with the Jungle Beach hotel which has very comfortable boats and especially a guide that accompanies you to show you turtles, sharks, and all the fish on each side of the island which is tiny. The equipment was perfect and when we arrived around 8:45am only 2 or 3 boats were there.From 9am the number of boats increases minute by minute.We were able to quietly observe 20 sharks 6 blue starfish turtles and a multitude of fish.You should not compare this place with Maldives, but given the number of tourists and their indelicacy this dive is really superb.

We got an offer from a guy, just by walking by the water, to have a trip with a boat next day. It was so surreal, no paper work, tickets, just a verbal situation. We did not know till the last minute if our trip will happen. But it did! ant id was amazing! You have to go and experience it your self. No shops, rentals, suveniers, no civilization, just wilderness on a small island. Everything was pretty relaxing, just have in mind, to have enought water, blanket to sit or cover ourself (from the sun), get some food with yourself, and you can have a very nice day like no other.
It's wonderful! But the price of the boat and the entrance are very expensive, you see brutal funds but it is not for all pockets

Visited Sri Lanka in the middle of the political crisis so Pigeon Island like everywhere else was very quite. We were concerned about leaving any valuables (only had phone and some small change) on the boat, but felt more than safe once we were there. It was a shame as others have said to have seen a lot of the coral destroyed and I really do feel more needs to be done to improve the eco-system here, even if it means closing to visitors for however long to regenerate, which I appreciate is a fine balance. However, we saw lots of fish, sharks and turtles which was really nice. A morning was long enough to take it all in and not feel too rushed.
Nilaveli  Beach Hotel organises boats at a reasonable cost. Many small black tip shark sightings. Many other fish and vibrant corals.

I have to say, that was much better than I expected. It‚Äôs true that there‚Äôs some dead corals but definitely a great variety of fishes. And lots of sharks. I‚Äôve seen 8 in literally 10 minutes on the side where the boats are coming from. I think they should warn people about how to behave as occasionally might chase swimmers (a local told me after). I got circled around and charged by 3 black tips, about a meter/and half long for 3 times. And I had to take refuge on the reef to escape. Not sure what went wrong as I‚Äôve been diving with sharks before and I guess when I started panicking, I did all the wrong things (sudden movements, splashing and shouting). But I had literally two of them on my fins while swimming away from them. Bad story, but I think should be mentioned for others safety. On this I‚Äôd like to add: boat price is 2500k period (locals and foreigners) don‚Äôt let other guys fool you as we got all sort of prices starting from 7000. Price included going there and back and you can easily stay all day with no price difference. We‚Äôve been charged 600 each for snorkeling equipment, which I also think is probably to bargain it down to 300 Entry tickets is now 10$ plus 8$ service charge per person, it‚Äôd be curious to know what is the service charge for. Locals pay 2$ total. Worth it but you could easily call it scam.

The place is beautiful, very little tourist currently. Snorkelling is amazing among sharks and large turtles, too bad it can't be done everywhere. The day is a little expensive for what it is, it takes 2500 rupees the boat ( 2min journey) + the entrance to the park 3500 rupees per person. Rental of mask and flipper (poor quality) 600 rupees
You can have an amazing boat ride to pigeon island . Their can do diving and smuggling. Very beautiful environment and can see colourfull . And also sharks plz never forget to keep that environment .

We were snorkeling around Pigeon Island. It is not hard to see sharks different sizes (up to 2 meters long). There were many sharks! Don't worry, it's safe. They are very shy. If you are lucky, you can see a sea turtle. Definitely you will see a lot of colorful fishes. But corals are there very poor. There are bordered areas and you should not go inside. Around them are corals destroyed by turists.

Our visit to Pigeon Island was an eye opener! we were amazed by the beauty of this place and would definitely visit the island again! It  truly is a national treasure! Negative reviews are likely by people who stayed in the dead zone near the beach. Pigeon is one of the best spots on Earth for beginner/intermediate snorkelers to see fish variety. I have limited experience of snorkelling but felt very safe in this environment. There are many different types of fish, the coral was magical and we also saw turtles and reef sharks.

Beautiful yet dying. The coral is on its last legs, there‚Äôs litter around the beach and it‚Äôs hugely expensive for tourists. 5800lkr for two people + 2000lkr for a boat over and back. The prices seems to vary day by day, we were told one price from people visiting recently and paid more on the day. I think it‚Äôs pretty much up to the ticket office to pick a number daily. It is beautiful, don‚Äôt let it dishearten you from visiting. When the sun is shining, you‚Äôll see plenty of life. Sharks, fish, turtles. It‚Äôs worth a visit, but only once. And soon. The coral will be gone before you know it.

Pigeon Island National Park in Sri Lanka Beautiful island Pigeon island, is located one km from the coast and the marvelous hotel in which we have stayed: Jungle Beach. It is a national park and a coral reef. Lots of coral dyed in the 2004 tsunami. The place is very beautiful and a destination that attracts local people and tourists. Some people may not like it because it can be crowded and difficult to snorkel in peace, but truly enjoyed. I loved seeing the families having fun, going into the water fully dressed. Mothers, daughters and grandmothers in their saris, so happy. It may not be the best place to snorkel, but is truly beautiful. My daughter saw six sharks and a sea turtles, besides lots of beautiful fishes.

We we went there as field visit from EUSL. The coral ecosystem and reef fishes were so beautiful. It was very useful for the subject 'fish biology' which we study. But my opinion everybody should experience this. Not only students but also others.

We went over on a Saturday so it was packed. I felt I was in a swimming pool as there were so many people in the small section of the bay on the back beach. As there were so many people the sea was cloudy. Unfortunately I didn't get to swim out of the bay due to personal reasons. The front beach is more quiet and has a protected section. I got to see lots of fish. jellyfish and a shark. I would suggest to bring swimming shoes as the beach is coral.

Get there early! We were on the first boat there at 8am and the crowd didn't show up for another hour or more. There is a snorkeling area that has a protected reef roped off. The water on this side of the island was a bit rough and there were many jellyfish in the water. You may be able to see reef sharks and turtles if you can brave the waves and jellys. We went to the other side of the island where there is a bit of a cove and were able to do some really relaxing snorkeling. There was no current and quite a few fish to see. Good area for beginners. Be sure to have water, towels, suncream, and snacks (if you want them). There is a bit of cover with some seating but the vast majority of the island is in direct sun.

I have never enjoyed snorkelling or imagined seeing the creatures we were able to see until this trip.  We saw sharks, jelly fish, squid, starfish, sea turtles and many tropical fish.  This was an amazing experience and I highly recommend it when in Sri Lanka!

Unfortunately many of the corals around pigeon island are already dead, that doesn‚Äôt mean that it‚Äôs not a beautiful place though. We saw lots of different fishes, one huge sea turtle and many (harmless) sharks. Don‚Äôt forget to bring enough sunscreen, a hat and maybe a white shirt to wear while snorkeling. The island was a bit crowded, but that wasn‚Äôt really a problem.

Pigeon island has small sharks and turtles too. We spent 3 hours there and we didn't regret. Visibility was nice, sharks were there, turtles also. Corals are average, but compared to the price I thing it was nice activity in Nilavelli.

Even without a guide it was easy to spot reef sharks and turtles as well as interesting fish. However the entry fee for foreigners just seems a bit high. We paid 5600, way more than for Kumana. Also the officials explained the fee was higher if you were fewer people which doesn't make any sense to me. Why should one person pay more for entering a protected area than two people? In the end we did enjoy our stay though and we didn't regret going.

I have read a lot of negative comments about Pigeon island, and I do agree that it is really sad that the coral very close to the shore has been damaged. We spent 4 hours on Pigeon Island and most of that time was spent snorkelling, first we went to the far side of the Island, if you are prepared to swim out away from the shore and the people then you will be rewarded with coral, shoals of fish of all shapes, colours and varieties, we also swam with 2 large turtles and watched them being cleaned by fish. On the side where the boats stop there is an area sectioned off for snorkelling, there were no people on this side, the coral is not damaged and we swam with a turtle and snorkelled on the surface while 5 sharks (4- 5 feet long) darted beneath us, for me it was a great few hours and an experience I will never forget.

Nice half day trip. Easy 10 minutes boat ride from our hotel Anilana. Beautiful water with a lot of fish. Couldn't find turtle. If you stay this area, worth to visit. Though it's a pretty island, it is pitty to see that many tourists stepping on coral that damages them.

We went in August and the ocean was full of jelly fish.  I was stung a few times - nothing serious that wasn't gone within 10 minutes of applying vinegar but it was a bit off-putting.  There is lots of beautiful sealife within easy reach of the beach, so it's well worth a visit.  Go early as it gets crowded in the afternoon.

Nice to see some tropical fishes, sharks and turtles but I had seen better in other places and frankly speaking it was over rated/over priced and over crowded (like many other turist attractions in Sri Lanka). Paid around 6,000 Rs or 40 USD for two of us for boat/entrance fee (we had our own equipments).

Its a beautiful island, a short distance away from the shore. Of course there are lots of pigeons hiding in the trees and not seen unless they are startled out of them by some noise. But its the snorkeling that's that attraction here. Shallow clean and clear blue sea with lots of beautiful reef fish. However the Sri Lankan Government's Department of wild life charges money for going to the island. Rs. 2,000/- per person. Locals have to carry all their identity documents and come to the ticket counter on the beach if they want to get the local rate. If they have come in their swimwear leaving the identity documents in the safety of the hotel, they too have to pay 2,000/- if they want to go to the island. However the Government  does not provide anything to the Traveler for the money charged. The Boats to go across are privately operated. They are unregulated and they quote as they please. Once on the island there are absolutely no refreshments. There isn't a place to even  get or by some water. There are no lockers to keep your Identity documents and other valuables. No changing rooms and no toilets. Absolutely nothing is given for the money charged. The government will be better off to back off and  save the money they spend as salaries on the dozen or so men stationed on the shore and the island, The locals in the tourist trade will do a better job  safeguarding the reef which is their livelihood. The private boat operators also have fins and masks which can be hired at a nominal fee without any limit on the hours of use.

Please save your time, energy and money for something else! We are a family of 4 who did a few snorkeling trips in south east Asia as we live in Singapore since 5 years. Was informed by two diving sites at Uppeveli beach that it was a much better option to visit other diving sites instead of Pigeon island itself as the coral was much damaged and the area overcrowded. I really should have listened to them!!! Really don't understand what's all the hype about this snorkeling site!!! A few nice fish on the other side of the island but were not lucky enough to see sharks and turtles... but one thing we saw was the very sad ongoing coral destruction!!!! Please just don't go and give this island a chance to survive!
Over crowded / All corals are dead Business over boats (only way to get there) make the journey expensive and with few service.

The place wasn‚Äôt that crowdy as expected (we went on the 4th of September). We were a little bit dissapointed by the snorkling (2 spots for snorkling on two sides of the islands). The area fot snorkling is quite small and most of the corals are gone. We were not lucky enouhh to see turtles, but some in our group have seen a big one. There are small sharks (1m) as well but those we only spotted from the beach.

We are a family of 5 with children aged 13, 19 and 20. Initially we were out off doing this trip as there were reports of overcrowding and reef damage. But on our last day we decided to give it a go. And we were so glad we did! It‚Äôs a beautiful spot, just 20 mins boat ride from Uppuveli beach. It‚Äôs a national reserve so permits have to be obtained by the boat man en route; a quick job. You need to visit both sides of the island to get the most out of it. The boat moors on the side viewed from onshore and u then walk across (a couple of mins) to the back side. The sea life is very different on both sides. The back side of the island has better visibility. Be warned there is a lot of broken coral and it is painful on the feet; if you have beach shoes or wetsuit boots bring them! Short fins which you can hire also work. We have done a lot of snorkelling/ diving all over the world and based on reports weren‚Äôt expecting much; well what a surprise! The abundance of different varieties of sea life was huge. So many different species of fish, squid, turtles and sharks. We saw 3 (think black tip sharks) at very close quarters on the shore side of the island. On the other side we saw turtles, incl a large hawksbill turtle who we swam with for some time. They have 2 types of turtle in Sri Lanka. At the time of our visit there were quite a few jellyfish but then it was just after a storm so it‚Äôs probably not always an issue. They aren‚Äôt poisonous but u may get a mild sting which soon goes. At some times of the year they have the ‚Äòred jellyfish‚Äô which is poisonous so check before u do the trip. The rangers hut on the island has vinegar which will relieve a sting. We really enjoyed this trip which was about 3 hours duration (though you can stay longer; we felt this was about enough). It was good value and well Worth it. üòä
Coral and snorkelling was nice but when we went it was very overcrowded - you could see damage to the coral was fairly severe and ongoing while we were there which was sad to see.

This is out of the world. I‚Äôm normally travel a lot and this is one of the best. It‚Äôs totally worth and should go there early morning. We had a guide who take us around the island. We saw turtle and sharks and colorful little fishes who looks so elegant.

Two friends, my wife, litte son and I went on a snorkeling trip to Pigeon Island. We did the trip from Uppuveli and it last from 8.30 am to 12.30 pm. Deducting the travelling time and waiting time for the national park tickets, only 2 hours were left for snorkeling. After the trip all of us had mixed feelings. On the one hand we were excited, because we saw sea turtles and sharks. On the other hand we were very sad, because due to the mass tourism the nature in and arround Pigeon Island really suffers. The coral reef around Pigeon Island is almost completely destroyed. Apart from watching sharks and turtles the submarine world offers a sad picture. Furthermore most of boats are quite old, i.e. many boats loose petrol and pollute the sea. All in all we can only partially recommend snorkeling on Pigeon Island. Although, the probability to see sharks and turtles is quite high, the impacts on the nature are terrible. Therefore we wouldn't do the trip again.

If I could give this place less than 1 star I would. It was heartwrenching to see how they treat the marine life in Sri Lanka. This is a national park and nothing is done to conserve the corals or fish. They had one small plot where you were not aloud to swim because they were preserving corals there. The whole trip was extremely badly organised. Noone spoke any English. Noone told people not to touch or step on the corals. The locals were standing on coral, shouting and screaming the whole time. I'm not sure if this is because of lack of knowledge and education? If it is this is really something the government should consider teaching if they don't want the whole sea to be ruined. I realize that this is a business opportunity for people who do not have much else, but this is not an honorable way to earn a buck. We got there at 8.30 and were one of the first boats. 30 minutes later you could hardly move around it was that crowded. The boats kept coming and going all trough the time we were there, crashing into each other at the beach. No safety whatsoever. The boat drivers didn't speak English and we were just given a broken snorkel and they told us they would come back for us three hours later. After five minutes in the water fending for your space we gave up and went to the beach. We saw a few fish, clearly distressed from all the commotion and people. This place is dying under water and it is all because of people. It was so sad to see... Most of the other western tourists we meet had the same feeling. There were a bunch of jelly fish in the water that sting. Badly. They did not give us any information about this and one girl had an allergic reaction after being stung on the neck. There are also some extremely dangerous jelly fish abit further out... Which we found out after being in the water. Turtles had laid eggs on the island the previous night and the locals kept running over the eggs, sitting on them and really not giving a f*** It was terrible to see the condition the corals were in and how the locals treated the place. Most of the locals can't swim and walked from coral to coral. The water was extremely murky due to the amount of people. This trip made me wonder what the conservation area are doing with all the money they get from arranging the snorkling trips. They had one trash can and it was filthy. No place to leave your things. No food or water. It was a mess. Do not go, for the sake of the corals and marine life please consider not going. We left two hours early because we were all so saddened by the experience!

I visited this place with my friends. You need to take a boat to this place and you can rent the snorkeling goggles. When you reached the island you have to cross and go to the other side of the island. There you can take a bath or go some deep for snorkeling. I would say it worth every cent you spent.

There is plenty of marine life to be seen here. I saw 1 turtle, 1 black tip reef shark and a multitude of fish. Our issue is with how it is being run. There does not appear to be any control over the numbers. We thought it was crowded on our visit but our guide advised that you can get times where there are 1000 people on the tiny island. Yes there are ropes that cordon off coral reef located within shallow water but people are ignoring the rope and standing on the coral. The first time I saw the turtle people were pushing each other to get pictures of themselves with the turtle, to the point where they were grabbing the shell of the turtle. Yet all this time there is a ranger sat in his hut doing nothing. We have snorkelled in various parts of the world but this was our worst experience. Sri Lanka has a very important marine park here but it is going to be ruined as the numbers visiting are only going to increase as more and more hotels spring up on this coastline.
Get there early in the day and it‚Äôs great. Heaps of fish and coral to see. Go to the leeward side of the island for best snorkeling.

Very expensive trip for three hours. Snorkeling equipment is in bad shape. Entrance fee, transfer and equipment altogether cost 8500 rupies for two people (2000 is transfer and equipment, possibly negotiated). More than 5000 rupies is fee but do not expect anything. In a weekday, there is from 8.30 to 16.30 around 2000 people on the beach of dead corals and another 2000 snorkeling in the sea. They step on the corals and kill them. They touch turtles and destroy everything. I wouldn¬¥t go there if I knew it. In the Weekend, it is even far worse. No locals are coming there as tourists are totally horrible.Neverever again!
A nice visit but there isn‚Äôt that much to see if you are expecting world class snorkeling. Still nice clean beach. Take your own food and drinks though. We spent 2hours there and that was plenty.

Set just off the beach - around a 15 minute boat ride away - is this VERY small island, which you can only get to 2 places. Most of it is barred - so don't expect to be able to wander all over it. We arrived very early on (boat no. 3) and by the time we left there were 15 lined up in a very small bay - so be warned, it gets very busy. There are no facilities there whatsoever either. The snorkelling such as it is, was good, BUT the reef has been destroyed by the Tsunami

Great snorkelling. Safe cove. Water was clear. Very clean beaches. The coral is being preserved by areas being cordoned off. Outside of this area you can see cuttlefush and basking sharks and a fellow traveller saw a turtle. There doesnt appear to be a lifeguard anywhere which is worrying and they have no first aid on island. I thought that if I got into difficulty, that would be it Good to take suntan lotion and water and towel for sunbathing

I was puzzled by the contradicting reviews of Pigeon Island with some rating it 1 and others 5.  So here's the explanation: 1. The bay where everyone heads to is small, massively overcrowded (00's of people) and any coral within 20 metres of the shore has been destroyed.  Anyone who doesn't past here will rate it 1 out of 5 2.  However, once you get past this there is some pretty decent snorkelling. The best coral was to the right as you face the sea so head over there and go out a bit further and there is plenty to see.  I've done plenty of diving and wouldn't be unhappy to see this on a dive. 3.  There is also good fish life here, we saw a Black Tip Reef Shark close up as well as the usual mix of tropical fish. 4. On the side where the boats come in there is a cordoned off area where they are trying to re-grow the coral and you can see an entire bed of new coral.  There is a rope surrounding the area that you can use as a guide - there were very few people here compared to the main bay.  It's good to see what the Sri Lankian authorities are trying to do here.

The island itself is very small but nice. A lot of people everywhere both on the island and in the water. The water was not really clear, the coral not in good shape but in 3 hours we saw four turtles (one quite big) and 2 black tip sharks. Alf way between the Nilaveli beach and the island we saw a young whale shark.

All visitors to Pigeon Island go there to admire the sealife on the coral reef. Although we went there during the low season, the place was very crowded; no coffeeshop or bar on the island - bring your own snacks and drinks.

I agree with both the good and bad comments on here: it is crowded, but if you're an ok swimmer you can swim beyond the hordes and there's a wide range of fish, some of the coral retains its colour and it's really lovely snorkelling, albeit in a small area. (By ok swimmer I mean a very strong 8-year-old or average young teen would be fine.) There are lots of jellyfish where the boats land, but a guide with a different group said they were harmless. One brushed against my son's arm with no ill effects, one lady was picking them up to photograph (!) However, the sight of so many of them is off putting. People do trample the coral, and the stamping about does cloud the water near to shore, but to be fair the coral starts at the beach so it's difficult not to stand on any. There were two roped off protected areas. One tourist, the first thing he did was swim to the rope, and duck under it into the protected area, so obviously the rules didn't apply to him. The boats pull up on one side of the island, this bit is very crowded and the sea a bit choppy, which could put off under-confident swimmers/ young kids struggling to master their snorkels. Walk over the spit of sand to the other side and there are even more people and more kids, but the water is far calmer and lots of people just stand in the water and don't swim, so once you're past them it's lovely and there are lots of fish - whole shoals swimming by. You can apparently hire a guide for an extra SLR 2,000 (about ¬£10) to 'show you the reef sharks, where the turtles are', and I can imagine if he took you to different areas the snorkelling would be amazing. But the standard trip is a good way to spend a couple of hours if you're holidaying in the area - I wouldn't deliberately travel there specifically for this though.

If you have tried snorkling already, then nothing will impress you here. The reef is practically dead and the visibility is far from perfect. Maybe you'll see a shark or a turtle, but nothing more than that. Place is definitely overcrowded, which kills the pleasure a bit. From Nilaveli beach I paid 3.850 rupees to get there.

Such a disappointment. We paid 3500 rupees per person (children too) which was a complete waste of money. But more importantly, this island is being destroyed by tourists. There is dead coral everywhere- all over the beach and in the sea. (If you do go, take swim shoes or your feet will end up scratched and cut. I cut my foot in the water). The island is tiny, it has two tiny areas to snorkel from. In both we saw nothing but a few odd fish, -after expecting reef sharks etc. So do not get your hopes up. No one saw anything it wasn't just us. Swimming is awful, everyone kicks you with their flippers and the constant stream of boats coming in creates large waves meaning your snorkel fills up with water. Please don't visit.

The island is the target of too many turist and too many boats. Almost all the corals are dead and the island itself looks like a crowd in a city centre. You get the ticket (is a huge paper) at the jetty point and the skipper ask you when he could pick you up and he is there at the exact time. You can't stay overnight and remeber to bring with you water as no shop are there. You may find some tiny jelly fish as well. You have to bring with you rockshoes absolutly. Swimming is nice to see big variety of fish but at the same tiem the large ammount of corals destroyed by the anchors and turist stepping on them. They try to say that the ammount of dead coral is due to the tsunamy, but is evident it is not. I strongly belive that Pigeon Island should be more preserved as it is a clear victim of the travel guides and tryp advisor. The volume of turism there is not sustainable at all in my point of view.

Visited the island on 01/08 with my family. I was aware the place is overcrowded and that we had to arrive early. We only made it to the island at 10AM and my first thought was the placed looked more like Picadilly Circus than a natural reserve! As many others have reported, the water is far too crowded to enjoy. We managed to see a couple of Black tip sharks, a green turtle and some nice tropical fish. The constant noise, splashing and banging will drive all fishes away over time I am sure. Let alone the poor coral being destroyed by careless swimmers. I experienced the bumping into other "swimmers" like others too. Authorities should really limit the numbers of visitors in a day if they really have Conservation in mind. Money obviously comes first sadly. Considering the entrance fee and the boating co-operative charges, someone out there is making a lot of money. I would not go back there again unless I hear some drastic changes had been made.

A 15 minute boat ride from Nilaveli beach brings you to Pigeon Island. We arrived around 8.45 on a Saturday morning. My family went off with their snorkels round an area cordoned off with ropes and bouys (a protected area) there were only a few other people around when the started, it took around 40 minutes for them to snorkel round the whole thing. By time they returned to the beach it was rammed. There were about 30 boats all waiting in the shoreline and there wasn‚Äôt enough space to put a pin between all the people on this tiny island. It was just getting busier and busier. There were so many people it was almost impossible to snorkel on the other side of the island. Lots of people were ignoring the cordoned off area and were oblivious to the rangers blowing whistles and shouting for them to get out. My family were lucky enough to see a turtle and a couple of reef sharks I saw some brightly coloured fish which was a highlight. There needs to be some sort of limit to the amount of people allowed on the island at anyone time otherwise soon here will be nothing left for anyone to see. Pretty disappointing. My pictures show what it was like before the hoards arrived.

Overcrowded with people, you can‚Äôt even swim without bumping into another snorkeler. The 90% of the corals are dead, you won‚Äôt see much more than their stoned carcasses, except for a few of them that still have a touch of color. Even though the few fishes to be seen are beautiful and very exotic, it was a mistake of us to go there in the first place and disturb the nature of this tiny island, that must have been an absolute paradise before humans set foot on it. For the people that have never snorkeled before, it is for sure pretty much of a great experience. But every footprint has an impact and before going, make sure to know the consequences of it. Having been there and regretting afterwards I would advise you not to go.

It's absolutely a nice spot, but not as good as many places in south-east Asia. It will definetely impress someone who has snorkelled only a coulple of times in their life, but if you plan your every holidays focusing on some fantastic places to see the underwater world, it may disappoint you. No matter what you're able to see underwater if every now and then you get hit by someone's fin. The place is so overcrowded that it's difficult to enjoy snorkeling. What's more, on one side on the island corals are terribly damaged by people who can't swim and just step on them. I saw one turtle and some fish. Nothing special in terms of snorkelling comparing with the Philippines and Indonesia. What I have never seen before was such a huge crowd of people and a complete chaos in the water. It took most of the pleasure of  me. My tip is, if you've seen a lot of good snorkelling spots in your life skip this place or at least don't expect a peaceful underwater paradise, it's not there.

The most of the tourist don't look after the corals, standing on them and hitting them with the fins. Its kind of a coral graveyard around the island. Lot of jellyfish, our boatdriver didn't mention if they were poisenous. Bad view under water. Don't go there in the morning, it's like a mass processing. A Nationalpark should be treated differently, with care not with reckless people.
An amazing array of beautiful fish - surprises around every corner. Boat hire simple and efficient. Best to explore a little off the beach where there is less foot damage.
The island is sooo crowded you can barely get in the water. All the corals are dead. You can se about 5 different types of fish, but that is it. Don't waste your time.

We did this snorkeling trip with our children aged between 8 and 12.  We saw nice fish, including a shark.  But most of the coral is dead.  In addition the area where we could swim was tiny and there were loads of tourists.  We were hit by the fins of other people who obviously didn‚Äôt know how to swim.  This is no world-class snorkeling spot.  And the mass of tourists made the trip a bit disappointing.

This is definetely a little marine  paradise surrounded by greenish blueish sea covered with coral reefs. You can absolutely enjoy the perfect combination of "3S"s.i.e.sea,sun and swim.Little boat ride to the pigeon Island from the coast of Nilaveli adds colour to your trip. Snorkeling would be one of the best things anyone could try over there. This was clearly an ideal holiday gateway for me.If you are a sea bird, you should never remove this place out of your list.
Nice place for snorkeling although there were too many people on the island simultaneously. Saw a lot if coral reef fish as well as a couple of reef sharks which was exciting!
Fantastic fish - gets crowded so come early! 10minutes from the mainland. Great mix of locals and tourists!

We took a boat to pigeon island, snorkeling gear was provided. Although still rather crowded (apparently weekends tend to get even busier) we could easily get some space to snorkel and see some really nice fish. The coral unfortunately is nit that spectacular. You do have to take for granted that in the island there is not much place to hide or get some private area
Very nice snorkeling. Wonderful coral gardens with a lot of colored fishes. Possibilities to see Blacktip sharks, turtles and others bigger fishes. Amazing!

We visited this so called magical place and was shocked to see the total neglect of the Nature of which these locals make money. The Island it self  is located short distance away from Nilaveli Town, which is renowned for its pristine beaches. This activity is totally mismanaged and boat service is run by a local Co-op Society . This place is totally overcrowded and to my amaze some local people get into these boats in their Traditional Clothes and totally unaware about the activity ahead. They go like on a Pilgrimage. It is so heart breaking to see that their total disrespect to the Nature . In my mind this is a total waste of money and time for a Western Tourist as some Tour Operators charge exorbitant prices for a non satisfactory experience with the local mass. Government intervention is badly needed for this unregulated operation , I will rather take a walk in these Pristine Beaches and not waste my money .

Went to the island with a really good dive company, very early in the morning. Got there at 9am and it was already crowded. There are only some spots of shade and no lockers or toilets or places to buy water so make sure to bring lots with you and be prepared to leave things on the beach unattended if you do go snorkelling. It's shocking to see the amount of tourism and what it has done to the island and it's coral reefs. The dive centre may be more money but with that we had a safe place to store our belongings, a guide who looked after us the entire time and showed us sites away from the crowds. He was also very strict about touching coral and keeping away from areas which were cordoned off to preserve the sites. Many tourists were ignoring these though. The coral a bit further out is amazing with an abundance of wildlife. We saw many sharks and turtles. Be sure to go early if you want to see these.
Nice little island not far from Nilaveli beach. Lots of colorful fish in the water. Please remember to keep this little wonder clean. You can easily spend 2-3 hours here.

Very easy to go to Pigeon Island from the main land. We could directly from hotel walk to the beach and book our boat and leave. The boat takes you in 10 minutes to the island and has snorkeling gear for you. It is a lovely place but once we arrived we were quite shocked about the place being already fully crowded at 9.45 am. Simply too many people on the island and in the water. Weird experience since the beaches on the mainland were empty. The snorkeling experience is nice once you pass the dead coral and swim a little more outside of the reef and other snorkeling people. We saw many beautiful colored fish (small and medium size) and even a black tip reed shark. We strongly feel that the rules of protecting the coral should be made clear and mandotary to every visitor: do not stand on the ground/coral and do not touch the coral. Else this whole place is dead within a year, given the number of visitors being not instructed well how to treat the coral.
To great place to go scuba diving but terrible for snorkeling. The coral reef is dying because there are way to many people on the island.

We went there as a family, on a rather windy day. Many others were there as well, so many that you were kind of snorkelling in a queue. The tiny beaches were full too.  The coral is nice some places, but quite broken other places. We saw the traditional Indian Ocean fish including smaller sharks, but it was not a spectacular snorkelling experience. And given the crowds I worry for the sustainability of the national park....
Just too many people - avoid if you don't like a crush.  Sadly most didn't seem able to swim and many were standing on the coral!

This place is well worth the visit but once you get there you‚Äôll find its really over crowded and polluted. There is a boat service from Nilaveli next to Anilana hotel that takes tourists there every 15mins or so. Need to take tickets. Good diving and snorkeling. However if you don‚Äôt like crowds and like privacy this is not your place.
Wow!! What a beautiful place! Fish everywhere in all colours of the rainbow!! Turtles, black tip reef sharks, coral reef, it was fabulous!! Well worth doing on your Sri Lankan adventures!!

Nice boat ride to the Island. As soon as you get there you see 100 of people snorkelling over to broke. Corall reef. We started out early, 8am, as we were informed the island becomes crowded later. The boat took us across to the island, about 10 mins ride. We were given life jackets to wear. Excellent clarity of water Great variety of Marine Life Excellent and Supportive Ground staff Superb location which is pristine Only, get your own snorkeling gear if you can

Paid around 30 usd / person for the boat to the island and the entry fee but I can say that it is really worth visiting the island. Is a really great place for snorkeling, the water is clean and you can see a lot of beautiful, colorful fishes. A short boat ride takes you to amazing snorkeling.  They take care of your rental equipment and guide you to see sharks and turtles and colorful fish.

Only 15 min (speed) boat ride from Nilavelli Beach Hotel. We took the hotel‚Äôs boat even if we were not guests to the hotel. Recommend go here for beautiful snorkelling. Go early in the morning as it gets crowded throughout the day. About 2 hours on the island is plentiful. The people who ran ran the business were very punctual and made sure we made it to the island safely. We then went snorkelling and saw the most amazing fish and corral. I highly recommend you do this if you are on the east coast of Sri Lanka.

It takes short boat trip (5000 lkr for one person) to island for snorkling. Many local people there at sunday. Its nice to see that coral is coming back in some places. Some area at beach was prohibited. Some corals and many fishes. No white sharks.

It takes 15 minute to go to PIgeon Iskand from Anilana hotel . Only you can go by boat to this place .. There are two pigeon islands . It is a beautiful little island, very scenic with clear water. As previous reviews pointed out, it can get very crowded and I was torn about going to not add to the issues raised.

Nice and safe place for snorkelling. Amazing to see a beach of coral reefs and not just sand and stone. My 12-year old daughter snorkelled too. Amazing snorkelling, with beautiful coral and a amazing array of marine life to be seen, including blacktip sharks, turtles and a huge range of tropical fish. However, some of the coral is clearly damaged, and more may need to be done to protect it.

A short boat ride here from the main land . You will come to this beautiful island for snorkelling! Water is so clear and you can see the coral, fishes and shark even within 100m radius ! Be careful of the coral rocks that may hurt your bare footed feet. Prepare your own towels and water is actually warmth that you can spend time with .

We visited Pigeon Island National Park recently (boat over to the island was 8100 rupees, 3000 rupees for the ticket for the National park) as we were staying close to it and it was definitely worth heading over to see. We got there around 8.30am and were one of the first people to arrive (it got quite busy after 9am with boats constantly coming into the beach) which meant going out to see the wildlife was much easier without loads of people around. I would suggest that it‚Äôs best to stay over there for about 4hrs (the boat captain will ask when you want to be picked up) as time does fly while you are snorkelling. We saw so many beautiful fish, a green turtle and even a shark. However, we were surprised in a bad way by the condition of the reef. It is deteriorating and they should protect the area more. Too many tourists are coming here. The number should be reduced and bigger area protected from snorkeling and boating.

As you alight from the boat after a short ride from the Nilaveli beach, you step on to a nature's paradise. Wow is the natural reaction of most first time visitors. More often than not, expect a somewhat rough boat ride since the sea is not very calm most of the year. Protect your camera gear from sea water splashes especially as you board and deboard the boat. Wear a hat or a cap, but beware of it flying off your head into the sea - mine did once!  If it happens tell the boatman. He will most likely pick it up for you. It's a delight to be in Pigeon island surrounded by crystal clear waters. This is one of the two marine national parks in Sri Lanka. The park includes the island and the sea around it teeming with colorful aquatic fauna. Beautiful reef fish, star fish, sea eel etc are abundant here. One can rent snorkeling equipment at the mainland and find an instructor to help you in the island. There are Navy divers on duty in case anyone has trouble in the water. This is a rocky mountainous island with dangerous cliffs as well. Such areas are marked with no entry signs. Please obey them, and make sure any kids in the group obey them. Having said that, make it a point to climb to the top through safe foot paths designated for that. You will be fascinated by what you can see from the top. For Photographers and nature lovers views from the top of the island are amazing. It's very windy up there most of the time. Protect yourself as well kids and elderly. At times, it feels like you are in the pathway of a small tornado!  Hold onto a tree and enjoy the scenery if you are not too sure whether you are about to fly off or not. Luckily the gusty wind is usually inward - not outward toward the ocean!  As the name of the island suggests, you are bound to see a lot of rock pigeons around - good subjects for photographers. There are quite a few butterflies, some birds and interesting lizards in this small island which is about a few acres in extent. During the season, I have seen quite a bit of land pollution. Please remember to take back everything you bring in, not to add this problem. Remember the number marked on the boat that brings you to the island. Otherwise, getting back can be an issue, unless the boatman can remember you! Every time I visit the fabulous city of Trincomalee I feel like re visiting the gorgeous Pigeon island for what it has to offer in terms of pristine nature.

I was one of the first people to visit this place from my family holiday home in front of it in the 1950‚Äôs It was pristine  with many colourful Carl‚Äôs teeming with reef fish and spiny lobsters IT IS NOW WASTELAND mismanaged ravaged and raped by greedy boatmen and the Dept

Definite value for money. Government ticket price is just LKR 345/- per person. The boat people try to make a killing. Be gentle with the Island and Corals
It's a Heritage site and the snorkelling (reef sharks) is amazing as are the dives (we did two), in one case simply walking off the beach

We went to pigeon island to see Some turtles and black tipped reef sharks. Unfortanetly we didnt see both of them. Sea was rough, corals were beautifull as were the many fish. We went as a large family party arranging boat ride, park entry fees and equipment rental in advance. Pick up was from beach directly outside hotel around 08.30, and then across to the island. Will literally come back only to this Island if I really have to. Amazing Small little gem with beautiful corals.

you should do that for sure. costs around 10$ -7000 RLK per person to get in there. sharks and turtles are always there. plus all fishes you want and lobsters we swam for 2,5 hours and that‚Äôs why we‚Äôre than burnt :( so do use some protection or t-shirt no food or water on the island do not forget to take underwater camera as we did :)

A group of six of us in our family including two children visited this dreamy island on 5th May 2018.  The entrance fees payable by foreigners to enter this National Park is 10/05 USD per adult/child.  The entrance fees for Sri Lankans/residents is between 1 to 2 USD.  We purchased our tickets at the Nilaveli beach near Anilana Hotel.  The boat hire for the one kilometre ride for all of us was Rs 2000 (USD 13).  It is compulsory for visitors to wear life jackets.  The sun was quite high up when we arrived there around 1000 and it is essential to apply sun cream before you get into the water.  The original inhabitants of the island, the protected rock pigeons have their nests atop the rocky mountain slope.  One can also walk along the many paths within the forest up to the top of this little island. People who do not snorkel enjoy a swim in the calm waters within the cove at the island.  Here too a little further out there are living corals clearly seen in pink under water.  Those who venture out on to the outer region do snorkel around the protected coral grounds to observe this underwater beauty.  There are people out there who rent snorkelling equipment for about Rs 250.00.  Some of the corals had been damaged during the 2004 Tsunami, but are now growing in the protected area.  There are lot of visitors too who may be unaware of the damage they cause to this pristine underground coral garden.  The many boats spewing out burnt diesel too add to this damage.  I believe steps should be taken by the authorities to make this location sustainable so that our future generations too can enjoy its beauty and serenity.

This is a brilliant place to go and I would highly recommend this. If you are 50/50 with your swimming they give you a life jacket to help you. Really we can freely snorkel wherever we like (we went round the entire Island with care, but probably shouldn't have been able to). Please take more care, once its gone - its gone and clearly the reef is highly stressed by the effects of climate change (which is probably the main pressure point).

This place is just an underwater paradise! The reef is beautiful and the fishes are abundant and oh so colorful! We loved every minute here didn't want to leave! We saw Sharks, Turtles ,Dolphins and tons and tons of wonderful sealife! Must visit!

Pigeon island has been one of the best experiences in Sri Lanka. Do not forget to have your diving mask and enjoy hours of snorkelling. Dozens of fishes of different colour, sea turtles even sharks &they don't harm swim around you. I will never forget it . It was amazing
First time in my life i was snorkeling with sharks! Unbelievable. So peaceful animals... many colorful fishes, few turtles, clear water. Go for it!
We have visited two times during 5 years period. I think this is the clean National park in Sri Lanka. All ages can enjoy at sea bath and view fish (even sharks) and corals.

Small island, where they do ship out everyone for snorkeling. Okay in low season, but it will be definitely overcrowded in high season.

This is an amazing place great snorkelling and saw a reef shark and lots of sea life and fish. One of the best experiences ever life guards are helpful too one of them went out with us. Be careful of jelly fish though.

This is a really nice trip if you love snorkling. It is better to go early morning, a lot of people want to visit this Island. It is wise to bring water shoes as there are a lot of stones. Unfortunately we only saw 1 shark and 1 turtle but we had a blast. We paid in total $70 for the four of us.

this place locate in Trincomalee, Sri Lanka, it is marine national park and situated 1 km off the coast of Nilaveli, a coastal town in Eastern Province, to reach that little Island there are boats and you have to pay for boat and snorkeling instruments, and its better to take Divers as Guides when you are visiting the Island , if you have diving and your own snorkeling instrument you can use that, water of the sea so clear you can see corals and coral reef fish in this area
Some of the best snorkelling we've done and seeing 3 large black tipped reef sharks was amazing. We were glad to see coral protection areas as a lot of the coral has been badly damaged.

Snorkelling amongst the coral reefs of Pigeon Island is an incredible experience. The waters are clear, warm and teeming with life. However, go with a reputable guide. This is a must do thing if you are going to Trinco. You will be able see colorful corals and many varieties of fish. Saw a sea turtle and shark as well. One of my best experiences.

It was my first snorkeling experience,one of best experiences in my life.There is a poster pasted on the ticket counter with pictures of fish you can see, and I could see them all!
