As I dint know swimming, was waiting in shallow sea at the back of island. A guide came and claimed that he can take me a visit through all the reeves for just Rs 300 . He took me all over the reef where I could see a variety of fish and corals that I never imagined. you need to reach there by a boat and buy tickets.There is no place to change clothes or take a fresh water bath after or to buy any foods or water.But you can hire goggles n fins.Unfortunately I saw many stay only very close to coast and enjoy seeing very little fish there, go a bit away from coast by your self ,if you know swimming or get the aid of a guide and explore more so that you can get the real value for the money you spend to get there.

We recently read the reviews on Trip advisor and decided we couldn't miss this trip so we were the first people on the island!  We arrived on the beach at 8am before the island boats depart (8:15) and ended up being the first two people there.  It is pretty and a very quick boat ride away.  There are two places to snorkel = one out front where it is a bit windy though you can see sharks (we saw about 13) and also a LOT of jellyfish which felt really weird - like swimming in a bowl of jello or jelly!  They don't sting though so all good. The other side of the island is quiet and calm and you can do some nice snorkelling and swimming. Other people and boats start arriving pretty much on the dot at 8:30 and the masses hit at 10.  Then it was actually crowded and not comfortable at all/  If you are a diver or have snorkelled in other places you might not see much but it is still a lovely experience and worth the trip if you have no expectations. There is nothing to buy on the island so bring some water and take your rubbish back with you.  They are doing their best to start protecting the site which is a good thing.

We loved the snorkelling on Pigeon Island! We saw sharks, turtles, tropical fish, sea cucumbers, coral, translucent with autoluminescense jellyfish and poisonous yellow jellyfish. You could tell a lot of coral was already degraded but quite a lot of the sea was now protected with very active wildlife guards on duty! Keep up the good work! You have to get a ticket from the beach to go to the Island and book a boat that will take you there and back.

We visited on a rather choppy day, but the snorkeling was still great. We saw with both sharks and turtles. Lot of amazing fish to see as well. There are two snorkeling areas. The sharks are in the front area. If you are in the area and love snorkeling, I would recommend.

Booked the snorkelling trip through our hotel, who arranged with a diving school to take us on a 4hour morning trip at Pigeon island. 3500 Sri lankan ruphees per person (includes boat ride & gear hire) This small island is beautiful and the snorkeling experience was amazing. Wide range of fish, sea turtles, sharks, blue water with fair visibility. No alcohol is allowed on the island. Pigeon island is one of the cleanest places in Sri Lanka. Was not over crowded Great sorkelling experience!
Beautiful and Devine island if you like snorkelling. Rough ground and corals but nice experience. Sun, warm water, short boat trip from the hotel. You need to take sun protection with you.

Fantastic experience, worth paying for the guide.  Up close with fish, turtles, sharks, and amazing sea creatures.   Best snorkelling experience yet ! Ohhh, don't stand on the coral and wreck it for everyone else.

This trip is definitely worth it, if you can manage to get out of bed early. To get there you need to do the following: 1. Get to Nilaveli beach in front of the Anilana hotel. 2. Buy tickets for pigeon island as early as possible (opens at 8AM and costs $10 per person and $8 per group) 3. The people there will show you to your boat which should cost no more than 2000 LKR (can be shared with up to 6 people) 4. Your boat will have snorkeling gear on it (mask, snorkel, flippers) which costs 600 LKR a day per person. 5. Your boat will drop you off in about 15 minutes but will NOT wait for you at the island. It will be busy bringing people to and from the island the whole day. 6. Agree on a time your boat will take you back, and it will be there. Following these steps we were first to enter the water. There is an area marked by buoys which you are asked to swim outside of to preserve the beautiful reef. Within the first 50 meters I saw a shark and a turtle having breakfast! It was absolutely stunning, and the reef was very beautiful. I have diving experience in the Caribbean and this place is definitely on par. I saw a bunch of amazing fish here! After about two hours of snorkeling I left the water and went to the other side of the island which is literally 50 meters away. Here you can also swim and snorkel. I spoke to someone who saw a giant eel! The island is very hot and you are quite likely to get a sunburn or overexposed to the sun. There is some shade but take caution. This is a must do activity in an otherwise quite simple town (Nilaveli).
It was so amazing that i was excited to see those corals. The water was also so clear. there were many fishes and specially "Blacktip reef sharks".Lets protect this islan and the COral reefs

Destroyed coral reefs, as hundreds of people snorkel here on top of one another, clambering over the reef. Not an experience I wish to have again.  Make sure to take a towel and drinking water as there is nothing on the island, other than swimming with a lot of people.

We arrived early at Pigeon island & were lucky to snorkel before the crowds arrived. This way we were able to spot a few turtles & sharks. Afterwards, the place became very crowded & the sight became very ppor. In fact, in our opinion there were too many people in the sea which will certainly have a negative effect on the corals. Morepver, the boat drivers drive like crazy on & off. Bring some kind of sandalls or swiming shoes when going to this place. The beach is difficult to walk on.

We saw some black tip sharks, loads of coral fish and nice reef. Other visitors saw a couple of turtles too. It's better to go early in the morning, it gets dusty  underwater with poor visibility due to crowd afterwards. I think in general people is damaging the coral reef, we should be very careful and respectful with it.

An unbelievable and unmanageable amount of tourists. The guides and hotels need to tell tourists about stepping on the coral, a lot of it is dead but it is heartbreaking to see everyone trampling over it.
Very clean Nice beach Great boat ride to Island Travelers need to be careful with broad drivers they might cheat the riders

I really enjoyed the snorkling here at Pigeon Island I saw many fish and coral sadly there were  lots of people so watch out for fins in your face. The guys driving the boats are keen to get to the next fare which is why I think they drove so hard and dangerously I seriously thought I would injure myself.

We visited Pigeon Island and did a bit of snorkelling there. If you go please make sure you take everything that you need especially a towel and water as there is nothing available in the island. The island is only accessible by boat and is about a 15 minute trip from the mainland. There is a charge for the boat and a permit to go to the park. It is an immensely popular destination and it's good to get there early. Snorkelling is not bad although where the snorkelling happens is on a lot of dead and damaged coral. The first thing we saw was a Black Tip Reef Shark which was pretty cool. As it gets busier snorkelling isn't quite so nice as people are rude and barge past you, kick you with their fins etc. Too many people in a pretty small place. It is worth the trip but go early to avoid the crowds.
The island is beautiful with white sand beaches and blue sea. After 11AM it is very busy. The snorkeling is not that great: you see some colored fishes and coral, but nothing special.

Yes you can see sharks ( black tip reef sharks) and a turtle if you are lucky but the island is way to crowded ( especially in the high season ) and tue to all the tourists the reef is also not in the best shape as many people don't know how to behave in the water and stand on corals. Also the national park is not going enough ( nearly nothing) to protect the reefs ....

Nice little island but not much to do apart from snorkelling. The snorkelling was awesome tho, with plenty of different fish, black tip reef sharks and turtles! Beach is fairly clean but mostly coral so not great from sunbathing on.

I will preface this review by saying I am not an experienced diver or snorkeller - although I have snorkelled before a few times in the Caribbean, Greece, and Egypt. Practicalities first - get there early. As other reviews state, it gets very busy. Having read other reviews I was very wary about the destruction of the coral. However there was a big blocked off area that was diligently patrolled by guards who whistled for people to move out when they transgressed past the buoys. The guide who took us out was also very strict about not putting feet down on coral and sticking to the allowed areas. For non swimmers there is a part of the island to paddle in and look for fish in the shallow sandy waters. This was even busier than the snorkelling side. So, to the views. The water was really clear and there were literally thousands of multi variety fish. Highlights we're seeing some very large black tip reef sharks, and even a turtle. There were quite a few jellyfish, so be aware of how best to swim through them (arms still and kick slowly according to our instructor guy). If stung it's not too painful really. This was a great place to see underwater life, and a lovely spot. It does get crowded, and if you go, please heed the warnings about coral and stick to the correct areas. Arrive before 9am and your experience will be greatly enhanced. This was definitely the best place I have snorkelled, and seeing the sharks up close was amazing.

This is the perfect place to learn to snorkel with young children. Sadly much of the coral is dead but the fish were impressive and visible from shallow depths. We swan with reef sharks as well. It was much more crowded in the morning. By late afternoon it was significantly quieter. This was a definite highlight of our trip to Sri Lanka for our children.
Nice place to snurkling. We paid on the beachr 8.250 rupees for entrance, boat transfer an snurkling goggles. It is very very very very crowded

We went early in the morning  we arranged everything at our stay Sea Zone Hotel. The boat and snorkeling set was included. You can stay as long If you want. 3 hours was enough. You first start at the back of the island in a bay. A lot of colorful fish and the water is easy. In front of the island is the current strong and you have to be a Good swimmer If you want to swim around the Riff. Your not allowed to swim in the riff. A guard Will whistle you back. We saw a turtle and a shark. Amazing. It is getting crowded later on the day.

Pigeon Island is clearly a naturally beautiful place but it won't be soon if development continues to be unsustainable. It was sad to see so much broken coral on the beach. The instructions are very amateur- everyone is just dumped on the island by boat and then told that one side is full of fish and coral and another has sharks and turtles. The fish side is overly busy and difficult to navigate due to slippy, dangerous rocks. People consequently stamp all  over the coral. The other side is cornered off to show some attempt to save the coral. On the fish and coral side, the coral was damaged but I did get to see an abundance of beautiful fish, such as puffer fish and jellyfish. The shark side was extremely rough to navigate and would only be for experienced snorkelers and good swimmers. I did get to witness a big reef shark which was very exciting. Due to the poor clarity of the water I felt like it was just me and the shark, which was really exhilarating. I was glad to visit but am genuinely worried about the future. It was nothing like the coral I've seen in Belize and Australia and the instructions were far less rigorous. With stricter guidelines, the reef will be protected better.

Please be careful to avoid touching corals with your fins !!! No prevention is done to avoid it, that's a pity. Snorkeling is beautiful here but if nothing is done to protect corals it won't last forever! Don't forget to bring water because there's no shop in the island.
It is expensive for what you see and FULL o tourist like an aquatic park. I wouldn't recommend it unless you want to waste your time and money...

Amazing time here. Did three different snorkels - each one delivering fantastic creatures: large peaceful reef sharks, huge graceful turtles, many varieties of vividly colored fish, moray eels, jelly fish, sea cucumbers to name but a few. The coral was also amazing to see. can anyone put some underwater photos of swimming with the reef sharks there.

Best place to do snokerin We went to Pegion island on 14th August... We paid LKR 3500 per person which includes boat ride and light snacks.. you can spend 5-6 hours at this place... Best place to do snokerning and get to see under water colour full fishes, sea turtle, corals and is you lucky then shark also.

A visit to this spot is a popular activity for both local and overseas tourists.   Bookings must be made to arrange the boat travel to the island, and the snorkelling facilities. must carry your own water and refreshments
We saw sharks and turtles. We booked the boat on the beach and spend around 3-4 hours on the island and in the water. Beautiful place.

A motor boat picked us up from the hotel and brought us to the island for a 3h snorkeling trip (4'000 rupees per person). Even though there are lots of people and the place gets easily crowded we enjoyed a great snorkeling. There's lots of fish to see on both sides of the island. Bring sun protection!

Snorkelling was okay, but way too many people are let on the island so the water was murky around the easy to snorkel parts. And one big toilet too, there being no facilities on the island. The coral was damaged in a lot of places, some nice bits though here and there. Saw a number of different tropical fish species.

Be prepared for a crazy amount of people: we saw more people on the reef around the island than in the rest of our time in nilaveli altogether, but well worth a visit.  Sadly most of the corals were wiped out by the tsunami, but some are slowly growing back and there are a good range of colourful fish along with the two real highlights: black tipped reef sharks and sea turtles; we got to see loads of sharks, and several large turtles up close! Be warned: it's quite deep out on the reef, and the water can get very choppy, so you might want to take flotation aids for younger children, or a guide to show you around - I strongly recommend Ravi, from the Pigeon Island PADI centre, who speaks excellent English and helped my kids so nicely, and took some fab photos for us, too!

We snorkelled here with our three children age 13,11 and 8. The 8 year old is a strong swimmer but found it quite hard as there was quite a swell in the water. We wished we had taken a life vest from the boat for her to use as it would have helped with her buoyancy. Everyone follows the same path out - here the coral has been totally destroyed. There is not enough advice about not walking on or touching the coral and consequently, many people destroy it. Once you are further away from shore and away from the masses, you can see lots of beautiful reef fish, reef sharks and Green Back Turtles. We really enjoyed it. Getting back to shore is more challenging as you have to go back along a roped area with broken coral underfoot. Go early in the morning - once we got back on shore after snorkelling, it was packed with people. You can snorkel on both sides of the island. There is some shade in the middle of the island but this was very crowded at the weekend.

What a shame! It must have been beautiful once but it has been over visited, destroying what makes it special. Yes there are some pretty fish and a few live corals but it is so crowded, I have been in less crowded public swimming baths. If Sri Lanka want to make eco tourism part of its offer, they have to do better than this.  See the pictures

I went with Shanker of Pigeon Island Dive Centre.  Cost was 5000rps (about $A45 but I suspect locals get there much cheaper).  He insisted I confirm my booking by SMS, then forgot to pick me up the next morning.  This made us late so Shanker got me a place on a later boat (with a defective engine)  from Coconut Beach in Nilaveli.  I had to pay for the Tuk Tuk to Nilaveli although Shanker came too and it was his fault he missed me.  The new organisers were surly and kept asking us to hurry up (for reasons I cannot understand).  We changed boats in mid trip.  I am an experienced diver (400+ dives) and I have rarely snorkelled in worse conditions.  Crowded, few fish, baking sun, poor beach access.  A hugely overused site and most disappointing.  To cap it off the boat to pick us up forgot to do so (he said he had problems with petrol but I don't believe him).  We had to ask another boat to take us and again change boats mid-trip.  What a shambles and lousy swimming too.

We booked through our hotel and were picked up by boat from the beach. The hotel supplied the snorkelling equipment. There was a wide variety of fish to see and although it was busy you could swim away from the crowds. The water is clear. We couldn't remember the number of our boat for our return pick up and it was a bit chaotic on the shoreline for dropping off and picking up. Our driver did eventually pick us up and was very apologetic for being late. Enjoyed the boat trip to and from the island.

Positive points first: we saw some beautiful coral, many colored fish, turtles and reef sharks, very awesome to see! Ideal for snorkeling. But, the way this island and reef is treated, all the beauty will soon be gone :( Hundreds of people, 20+ boats. People are walking on the corals constantly. Near the coast the coral is already completely destroyed. But farther out we also saw people constantly hitting the corals and standing on them. It's a matter of time before all the corals will die. Then the small fish can't live there anymore. Then medium fish can't feed anymore. Then the turtles and sharks will go away because there will be no food for them. This is basic ecosystem logic. If the organizations around pidgeon island don't start to do some serious conservation actions, then they can soon all close their businesses because there will be nothing to see underwater. Right now pidgeon island is a money machine. It should be about the beautiful underwater world that us humans are allowed to respectfully visit and observe.

If you are on the east cost of Sri Lanka you should definitely go and enjoy a snorkelling session in Pigeon island! The departure will be from Trincomalee by speed boat for 10 to 15mn. There are basically two snorkelling spots but careful because there are a lot of jelly fishes. Good point if that we saw some sharks (not dangerous ones) - apparently possible to see some turtles as well... Fees entrance (+boat ride) are quite expensive as the rest of the touristic places  in Sri Lanka!

If you are in the area it is definitely worth getting a boat out to this tiny island for some great snorkeling. We saw a huge turtle, lots of reef sharks which we had never seen before and which swam right by us, as well as countless other hugely colourful tropical fish. It is only about a 10 minute boat ride from Nilaveli beach and you can hire the snorkeling gear from lots of outfits in Nilaveli or on the beach

We went there from Uppuveli beach. We arrived by tuktuk in time. We had to wait for 45 minutes. Then they want to split us over different boats. We told them we did not want that. Then we had to wait for half an hour they told us. We ended up going directly, but with too many people in 1 boat. On the way back we had to switch boat on the middle of the see. Annoying, especially because the boat people were not communicating well. They only have us orders: 'help ', 'quick', 'out, etc.. . The snorkling was fine, especially at the other side of the island. We did not see sharks or turtles, but a lot of beautiful fish.
In fact the best place for snorkeling provided that the whether is conducive. There are many resorts nearby which provides boat services. Bit crowded, but amazing.

A lot of tourists you must arrive at 9:00 when it opens. If you are a good (I mean a really good swimmer) ask your guide to show you the real thing. It is sad that people are walking on corals, how can they do not know it's alive and take so long to grow!!! Please if you go there be careful not to walk on corals....we saw sharks and fishes it was nice...

We went early in the morning - leaving Nilaveli at 8:30 am - and managed to avoid a fair bit of the crowds as well as arrive when the water was clear. You can snorkel both sides of the island. The side you arrive on has turtle and black tipped sharks but the other side has a greater diversity of fish particularly if you snorkel out around the little rocks/islands. There is some damage/die off of the coral, particularly close in. However, I was expecting this to be much worse based on the reviews I had read. I really tossed up whether to actually bother going, but it was well worthwhile - saw some amazing reef fish with. a lot of diversity.

We have just come back from a trip to Pigeon Island from our hotel Uga Jungle Beach. The hotel wanted 50$ per person to take us 9km down the road to Nivalli beach and to buy our tickets for the boat ride and entrance fee. We called our driver who took us for free!  Anyway the costs are 9000 RS for 2 of us for the boat and the island. The island is a 10 minute boat ride away. There are no facilities on the island - no toilets or shop and the ground is quite stony so take some water shoes if you have them. Our driver advised us to take only our towels and snorkelling kit as you basically leave everything on the shore whilst you swim. We also took some bottled water which was useful. One thing I would say is AVOID WEEKENDS.  It was heaving over there particularly with locals who were all swimming in their clothes and underpants -it was like a Sunday afternoon at the local swimming pool at home!  Unfortunately the water was not very clear - not sure if this was due to the amount of people in it or the recent rains, and it was also quite choppy and difficult to swim the further away from the shore you got. We only saw the normal types of tropical fish and no turtles or sharks unfortunately. We have seen videos from others where the water was much clearer and they definitely saw turtles and more, so the moral is don't go at weekends or when's it's too windy/choppy.
that the recent surge in tourism has damaged the reef to a degree, so don't expect a pristine marine environment. Close to the shore, some day trippers stomp all over shallow coral

I was looking forward to our trip to pigeon island for snorkelling. we were picked up by a speed boat from the beach at the hotel and whisked over. This is definitely not a quiet, quaint place to snorkel and relax! there were hundreds of tourists packed into the snorkelling areas making it very tricky, that coupled with the many rocks and sharp lumps of coral made it not the day i was expecting. After a few cut feet and hands i ended up taking the kids into the rock pools to look for fish and animals which was much easier and we did see a lot in there! the other downside was the constant changing of prices and trying to get more money out of us by the boat/snorkel people from what was initially agreed upon before we left.
I was snorkling with my 7 year old son and he loved it. We saw sharks, seaturtles and many different coloured fish.

I loved it too visit this national Parc, but it is a small island and full with tourists, the coral was also not beautiful, I saw other places with very beautiful coral, a lot is destroyed here, very sad actually! There is not a lot of fish, but I saw a shark, that was amazing!

My family and I went to the Pigeon island last week and riding on the boat was probably the best part of this whole experience. If you decide to go there, our advice is that you go there really early in the morning when the water is still clear. You can negotiate for the price the evening before (we paid 20‚Ç¨/adult which includes the boat ride from Nilaveli, the entrance fee and the snorkling gear - according to the owner of our guest house this is about as low as possible they would go with the price at the moment), take your breakfast with you (as of course you can't buy any food or water on the island) and make sure you arrive there as early as 6.30 or 7 o'clock in the morning. Later, around 9, hordes of people arrive and at one point, it seemed there were more people than fish in the water. As for the coral reef, other reviews give a clear picture of what is left of it. You do get to see quite some nice fish, while the coral reef itself is basically dead.

We heard this was an alternative to the busy pigeon island. The spot is a few km's north of Nilaveli beach. First we were taken on a boat trip up the relatively uninteresting river, later snorkling off the coast. Both were mediocre, especially for the price asked (18$ pp). Would not recommend.

We were planned to go to Marble beach on a hot day. We were 5 friends went. We stayed in an Inn in NC road, Trincomalee. Morning nearly at 9 o'clock we went to marble beach. We hired a boat there. It cost around 3000LKR. And with the boat, they will provide you safety jackets. Also, we bought goggles for another LKR1000. Then it will take around 5 - 8 minutes to reach the pigeon Island from the shore. Bring some sun creams because it was really hot there and there is a high possiblity of getting the tan. We spend around 2.30 hours on the Island. After coming out, you will feel hungry so take some snacks with you. It will be really a fantastic time on the Island. It will be more joyful to people who love beach like me.

A little over crowded at certain times of the day, the swimming and snorkelling area is away from the boating channels and parking on the beach. Expect to pay rs2,500 each for your visit. There are a couple of benches to sit on in shade but no facilities or kiosk so take your own water and food. The snorkelling is amazing with lots of beautiful fish to see. Please take care not to damage the coral.

We went to pigeon island today. We were really shocked when we arrived. The whole island is full of people and boats. Around 11 I counted like 27 boats and probably 200-350 people. When we went into the water we realized that the reef was totally broken by all the people. Because they just walk over the corals. You don't get any briefing how to snorkel carefully. I'm wondering what they're doing with the entrance fee of around 12$ per person. It seems that it's not used to build an infrastructure and a sustainable tourism. We got a really bad conscience that we went there. I can't recommend anybody to go snorkeling there.

We saw many beautiful fish, turtles and a reef shark but this reef needs some love and care and no visitors would help. Very overcrowded conditions for snorkelling with many people standing on the reef. Some sections are roped off to protect it but more needs to be done. We went on the advise of a friend who had been there 6 years before, said it was quiet and stunning snorkelling, a lot has changed in 6 years, not the place we had imagined.

The snorkeling at Pigeon Island is incredible. Colorful corals and a mass of marine life. We were lucky enough to swim with a turtle, 3 reef sharks and a whole host of other fish. The downside of this area being such a good place to snorkel is it attracts large crowds. So the areas nearest the beach are full off people and you have to watch where you are going carefully. Also when we came across the turtle is did not take long for a group of around 20 people to start crowding around it which seemed a bit of a shame. So the area is fantastic, but I would try and go at a time were it is not so crowded. We went between 10-1
We went at the end of the day. Nice place for snorkling. We saw many different fish, even sharks! Nice boatride.

We have snorkled and dived many places around the world so actually we didn't have the highest expectations. However we were positively surprised. There was a nice reef and we saw many black tip reef sharks, a few turtles and a lot of other fish. We paid 25 usd for the boat and the same per person for entrance since it's a national park. I can't give 5 stars. Too many people on the island and no snorkeling instructions. I saw several people standing on the live reef which is sad. The reef is completely dead in the area where people enter the water.

I visited with the hope of seeing turtles and I was very fortunate to see 2! The coral had certainly seen better days and the water at late morning was a little murky in the deeper areas but there were lots of colourful fish and in places, some bright coral formations. I agree with previous comments about the amount of tourists (and boats!) needing to be controlled. Perhaps they should close the national park on a day or two a week and educate people on how to behave in a delicate underwater environment (follow the lead of Hanuma Bay in Hawaii). I was delighted to see turtles but the experience was somewhat tainted when a man in a large group decided to swim down and grab the turtle. Myself and one other told him loudly that this was NOT OKAY but despite this another man in the same group proceeded to swim down minutes later and did the exact same thing. I repeated my statement of how this was a national park and the animals should be left alone and merely observed (which was rather more difficult than it sounds when you're treading water and wearing a snorkel mask). When I returned to the shore I told the men at the ticket office I had witnessed 2 men handling a turtle, they just told me to tell anyone doing that not to... and thanked me when I told them I already did that. They just didn't seem that bothered which was sad but it was evidence of the general behaviour regarding the protection and maintenance of this reef. If they could put some regulations and education in as part of the trip I would  be happy to visit again, as it stands I would not return.
go there it really worth it, too many tourist but if you go on the opther side of the island it's another thing. lots of sightseeing of any kind of marine life, also reef sharks.

If you are after seeing lots of dead corral, and people standing on rocks in the water, perilously close to the last of the remaining corral, and seeing a few colorful fish, all the while with a good chance of encountering lots of jellyfish, well then this is the place for you. What this theoretically beautiful place really needs is an end to the steady stream of careless tourists. I try to avoid places like these, but didn't today. A very sad mistake.

We went to Pigeon Island as part of our tour of Sri Lanka with our private tour guide who also came with us to the island. The island is a 10 minute boat ride from the beach. Our guide was able to negotiate a deal for the boat crossing there and back, the tickets for access, hire of snorkels, flippers and flotation jackets for about ¬£35 each, so we paid ¬£70 for the two of us. Well worth the money as when we got there it was busy but not too quiet, lots of locals go there on a Sunday to enjoy the water and to snorkel. If you plan on going then a few musts to remember, the beach is a coral beach so take sometime to lay on, on the Island itself there are no facilities AT ALL. No toilets, apart from the sea, no sun beds, seats or any place to get water. So take what ever you need with you, make sure you take water, sun tan location, any food you want etc. The island itself is small and there are two small beaches, one where the boats all pull onto and the other side just a minutes walk away where you can snorkel. The coral reef is about 80% dead but there are some stunning fish in the sea and still signs of life on the coral. Great place to relax for a few hours to snorkel, lay in the sun and read a book. Place can get busy so go early and work on having a good half day there just to chill and relax. Just remember to take what you need with you as there is NOTHING on the island.

A short boat trip from the beach at The Nilaveli Beach resort, the Island has two snorkelling areas only metres apart on each side of the island.  The snorkelling is better on the southern side. We saw heaps of reef fish and turtles.

When we booked to go snorkelling at Pigeon Island and after reading the reviews, I was expecting to see a huge number of fish. In reality it felt like there were more people than fish. I was expecting to be able to snorkel off the boat (for the price) but everyone walked In from the beach - thus damaging more of the coral. I have snorkelled many places around the world and we went to Nivaveli just to do this but I wouldn't have bothered if I knew now what I knew then. It was quite expensive-park fees alone were more than $10 and for 3 of us it added up to more than $100. The boat trip (only about 10 minutes) was the most exciting part - and meeting people from many different countries.

We travelled to Pigeon Island twice over two days because it was so beautiful. Perhaps this was the best time of year (bit hot! but water clear), and we saw sea turtles, reef sharks, lots and lots (tons) of colourful fish, and of course the coral! Truly a OMG experience for all of us - family friendly. We ended up renting snorkels and masks and flippers from the boatman, but better if you already have your own (hygience etc at least for the snorkels and masks). Renting snorklels / flippers / masks is 600 LKR per item rented. There is a great chap on the island, Sujji, who helped our kids and us to really enjoy the snorkelling (we are utter novices). He is v v kind and a real asset for the island. The first time we went to the island it was around 1200, and the place was pretty crowded. However this didnt dilute our experience - the wildlife totally ignores humans. The second time we visited at 1400, and stayed till 1730 - as Sujji told us, the afternoon is best for seeing the elusive turtles (and we saw 2!!). Also, the heat means that the human crush is less. This was June so may be different at other times of the year. What can I say - the singular experience - apart from seeing bottle nosed dolphins at 0630 on a morning shipride - for us all in Trinco! NOT TO BE MISSED!

Me and my partner went snorkelling here the other morning, it cost us 3,800r each but this price varies on the size of your group (our group was 4 people). We saw loads of different fish, a turtle and a black tip reef shark which was interning. However, the place is very over crowded and for the price we paid you can't really get your moneys worth!! We got there for about 9.45am, so I can't even suggest going earlier.

We paid Rs3500 each for a boat and snorkelling gear (from Uppuveli). I guess it may change throughout the season but at the end of June there was poor visibility and very choppy water, so not great for snorkelling. There are a fair few pretty fish but we didn't see any sharks. Not worth paying for the trip in my opinion, as the Pigeon Island beach is just the same as the mainland.

In all honesty this place is not the best tourist attraction in the area, far from it. The island is made up of dead coral which was very sad to see. It is also sad when you consider the measures in place in other countries to save their coral which Sri Lanka have ignored - and are paying the price. Amongst the dead coral there's plenty of plastic waste for you to see. Cost 6700 rupees for the boat and tickets for 2 and went early to beat the crowds. After about half an hour (9:30am) it got very busy with flippers in everyone's faces and low visibility. There were so many boats that they wouldn't all fit in their designated area! All of this coupled with very high winds and low visibility meant we saw plenty of fish but no turtles or Reef sharks. All in all it was something to do and something to see but it will never compete with other countries.

A great (half) day trip by boat from Nilaveli beach, about 10 minutes away.  Don't overpay by going with your hotel, you can do it for a fraction of the price - there's no difference in what you get!  We went with Ashok based at Coral Bay Hotel, our dive centre next door told us about him. The snorkelling is great at Pigeon Island, plenty of fish especially a myriad of different parrot fish, there are corals too, but sadly much of it is dead and damaged.  We were shocked at the way a lot of visitors were standing all over it - do they not realise the damage they are doing?!  It's good that you can swim and snorkel in any areas but really there should be some control/guidance to help preserve what's left of this precious site.  It was also very busy, perhaps again numbers of visitors should be controlled, You can snorkel on two sides of the island - we saw some impressive reef sharks who swim really close. Take suitable footwear (we used our wetsuit socks) as the dead coral on the beach is hard/sharp to walk on barefoot when you get off the boat especially with the heat of the sun.

Terrible tourist trap. Overpriced at 3500 rupees. To make it worse, they even dare to ask tips after the tour (coconut beach lodge). But worst of all is of course we re destroying beautiful coral reef, unknowing tourists stepping on the fragile nature. You can just see the coral dying. Disgusting commerce.

Overal the visit was nice. We saw some fish and 2 sharks which was fun. Also at some spots there was nice coral. We paid 3000LKR for a boat, gear AND the parks entry fee at a place in Trincomale. The service was perfectly fine, especially for the price. I wouldn't pay more then this however due to much of the coral being dead (by tourists and locals inconsideratly handling the coral). The beach was full of the dead coral, deeper in the snorkling route there where some OK corals. The fish where nice and they would be my main reason to go there.

The coral was great to see although it was overcrowded. If your lucky you get to see reef sharks and turtles. For being a tourist you have a hefty price to pay to enter the national park, pay for the boat and hire of the mask and flippers. Best to get to the beach early and boat share to save money their. And makesure your mask is adjustable before you leave because the majority of the masks were falling to bits.

We visted on a rather choppy day, but the snorkeling was still great.  We saw with both sharks and turtles.  Tons of amazing fish to see as well. There are two snorkeling areas.  The sharks are in the front area. If you are in the area and love snorkeling, I would recommend.

Pigeon Island is amazing. If you want to do snorkeling in Sri Lanka this is the best place. There are plenty of corrals, fish and other sea creatures. Because of the war took place in the country this was not accessible so probably thats why its so protected. i really hope people will look after this site. I can see that precautions are taken. Like you cannot go in your private boats as you want, you have to take tickets and then permission. There is a wild life representative at the site so look after. Well there are private companies who take you to the island and you can borrow snorkeling equipments from them. they take you to see the corals. I have gone with the hotel (Jungle beach). Wella who took care of us is really great. he made sure that we see the creatures. I could not believe i swam with a shark and a turtle in their natural environment. i saw pretty amazing beautiful fish and corrals. this is absolute must do things in Sri Lanka
We swam with sharks, turtles and fish in all colors - over beautiful coral reefs!  Highly recommended!

We came to Nilaveli beach for 3days/4nights so this was a nice trip off the beach. But I was a little disappointed with the coral- pretty dead all around even if you try to venture further out. However there were fish and some colorful sightings but nothing to write home about. We went with the Padi folks next door to our hotel Cardamon and paid LKR 4000 for the ride, plus a ticket for the national park and snorkeling gear. Have seen better but if you have time and want a trip away this isn't too bad.

Definitely worth a trip if you're in the area. The fish and the coral were amazing to see. Unfortunately I wasn't lucky (or unlucky) enough to spot any sharks or turtles which was a shame, but thing some other people did that morning.

What an awesome place! I am a bit "snorkel level basic" but even so managed to have a great time snorkelling with sharks, turtles and cheeky looking fish! The corals looked untouched and even though there were many people there was still a great experience! If I could only do one thing near trinco it would be this!!!

Great experience, worth the money. We arranged with two other people staying in our hotel and shared a boat. We paid around 3200lkr, including snorkeling gear...Boat costs 2000 lkr (the whole boat, not per person) regardless how many people, ticket is 2000 lkr per person, snorkeling gear (fins and mask) is 600. Make sure you go on a sunny day, to have better view in the water. We saw sarks, turtles, corals and loads of colorful fish. Very nice, little island. You can also find some shades on the island to rest.
Nice place, but definively too expensive and over-crowded. It's a pity, while snorkelling, to be surrounded by more humans than fishes....
We saw baby sharks, turtles and all kinds of other fish, felt like in a middle of an aquarium. Never experienced snorkeling like this before. Just amazing!
we went pigeon island on may that was amazing moment for us there too much different corals and we snookering there
Very nice trip with a lot of people though. I have seen something between 5-8 sharks including babies from a very close distance. It was really really nice and I recommend it to everybody.

Lovely to see so many healthy young corals growing and I esp enjoyed seeing the sharks. I half dived half snorkelled during my trip. Pigeon island gets really busy for a more interesting experience you might want to consider scuba diving with Nilaveli Diving Centre at nearby Crow island - some great coral & lots of underwater life.

Amazing experience of swimming with turtles and sharks although the coral is very damaged. Sharks were circling around us and the turtles were right next to us. Worth the experience to see them and go early. We were the first there and it was nice to swim for a bit on our own before the masses of boats arrive.

There are a plethora of operators taking people to Pigeon Island from around the Trincomalee and Nilaveli area. They only seem to care about the money.  Price appears to be around 3,000-3,500 rupees, depending on operator and location. This includes the national park entry ticket... However, when we went with one of the operators from Trincomalee, they did stop at Nilaveli 'for the tickets', but I didnt see any exchange happen. No briefing was given on the boat.  This is ridiuclous and explains how some of the visitors behaved and why the site looks as it does. In a national park where people are going snorkelling, good operators should be briefing their guests, a little on safety, but mostly on what NOT to do while snorkelling and visiting a national park. There were total muppets STANDING on the coral, the worst offenders for that were actually Locals, and telling them to get off the coral just resulted in oblivious stares and head bobbing. People should be reminded about using their fins correctly, and not bashing them around while bobbing vertically in the water and crashing them against the corals also, plenty of people were guilty of this. The operators allowed people to "swim" in life vests AND lifesaver rings.  Not ocean/pool floaties, they were actually swimming with the life saver ring from a boat around them.  Utterly ridiculous.  Those are rescue materials, not toys. People were smoking in the National Park beach arwa, and dropping their cigarette butts in the sand.  Another thing that should not be permitted in a protected area. The Government needs to step in, and they need foreign help with how to run a National Park as the Sri Lankan operators dont seem to have a clue or give a darn. The Island is quite small and you will likely be pointed to two areas, one on the opposite side from where you land - full of dead coral, mostly colourless aside from the fish, which you will see more of if you swim further out and away from others. On the same side as you land, there is a area marked with a rope, people were swimming both inside the rope amd around it - no instructions were given regarding this and no one seemed to care what anyone got up to on the island or in the water. On this near sode, there are more live corals, particularly if you swim away from where the more timid and often careless stand-on-coral people are, slightly less fish but more black-tip sharks spotted here. Overall, I enjoyed a lot of what I saw once away from most others, but it certainly isnt the most amazing snorkeling I've done, and there is a distirbing amount of dead coral which is only going to increase as no one seems to give a crap about ensuring the site is visited with care.

We had a very nice trip with a boat we rented from our hotel(cardamon nilaveli) and a super nice guide who showed us around the island, we were able to go out further the sea because he knew where to go and we saw turtles, sharks and many fishes, after we walked around the island. There might be better spots to dive because of the high damage of the corals but for snorkelling it's fine. For sure a really nice trip If you go in the morning before all the tourist groups come
We had really good time in this island, snorkling was so cool ! We saw little shark, tortles, a lot of beautiful fishs ! Good place for spend a day !
Rather barren island, so take whatever you need when you visit. Great snorkelling, 2 resident black-tip reef sharks, lots of marine life, some beautiful corals, well worth a trip for the non-diver.

It nice coral reef. You can see here turtles, sharks, lobsters and more than 300 types of fishes. Best time to come 8 at the morning on first boat. Only till 9 at the morning possible to see turtles and sharks
Pigeon Island National Park is one of the two marine parks of Sri Lanka. we can go this place with boat

Our objective was not snorkeling, so we went inside trekking to see the whole island. The island has a hillock where the pigeons throng The water is deep sea green against the white sand which look beautiful. Best time to reach nilaveli beach is 8am to purchase the tickets for 2 reasons: Beat the heat before the sun is scorching & before the crowd makes the island a fish market.

We went there with the first boat and went snorkeling immediately. We were so lucky we did. We saw sharks, turtles and lots of fishes. During our seconds snorkeling we haven't had as much luck because first there were sooooo many people and second the drain came. So beeing there early is the best. After going snorkeling right away you can go swimming on the other side of the island (be carefull if there are jellyfishes) or wandering around the island (there are paths)
Snorkeling in Pigeon Island is *really* quite awesome.  We saw a giant turtle and lot of small sharks.If you swim further out there are some really beautiful fish and coral to view,
Fabulous place to snorkel cannot recommend highly enough. Black-tipped sharks, turtles and wonderfully colourful parrot fish. Don't miss Pigeon Island!!
This is one of the best Island Park in Trincomalee  of Sri Lanka. You can go by any of those boats which take you up and down. Worth the visit

The Island is well maintained and controlled by authorities. We even had a guide from the forces who assisted my kids in snorkelling who saw reef sharks and turtles. Only be aware when renting swimming gear from the boat folks as if you don't negotiate the price upfront they will rip you off upon returning items.

This is a must visit place. Great if you can swim and have snorkelling experience. Need to buy tickets and then you ll have to pay 2000 LKR for the return boat trip. You can rent snorkelling gear from the boat people but those are dirty and low quality so bring your own if possible. I want to thank Police life guards in the island. They are very helpful. Gave us a free lesson and help us to have great time there. Dont take valuables as there is no lockers and please dont leave any rubbish.

A quick speed boat ride and you are  there. Snorkelling ok but watch the current. Water is clean and warm and it's very pretty with soma fish viewable from the shore but also some stinging jellyfish. Very crowded on S.L. Weekend but still fun.

You must take a Snookling set with you to enjoy the view under water. You can swim with sharks and turtles with a minimum risk, but please don't step on the reef. Costed 300lkr for the entry and totally worth it.

The most surreal snorkelling experience I've had thus far. You get to swim with many coloured fishes, but the highlight of our trip is seeing reef sharks and sea turtles. Beautiful! Please be mindful not to leave garbage and plastic there. It is a beautiful place, please don't ruin it.

It seems easy: just call s/t a National Park and you can ask 25-fold the entrance fee from so called foreigners than from locals. Ad some 2000Rs. for transfer and get shipped to a small nice Island with lots of dead corals and some fish. Listen to crying babies an loud locals. Snorkeling really is nit worth it. I can not recommend this place.

You will need equipment for snorkeling and a boat ride to the island. Most probably, those can be got from the hotels you would be staying. For both, as I can remember, costed around 6000 LKR per person, for us. In the island, there are people who will help you to do the snorkeling at far from the beach (around 1km), to be able to see turtles and small sharks, if you would like to have their help. We gave him 1000 LKR as there were 2 of us. You should check on this amount to pay as we are not sure we paid more. And, there will be a ticket for entering the island around 400 LKR per person. So, better to have around 2000 LKR to bring with you if you are going as a couple. But, don't take your purses and valuables there as there is no place to keep them safely. You can do snorkeling very close to the beach if you are not a good swimmer and yet you would be fascinated to see the beautiful fish there. And, be careful of the Jellyfish as they can be allergic to you if they are touched. Before, going to the island, you should check the possibility of going there from your hotels, as you won't be allowed by the navy based on the condition of the sea and it is changing day-to-day. So, plan your trip based on the weather condition as snorkeling at Trincomalee is a MUST!

Accessed the ticketing office through the Nilaveli Beach Hotel road. Ticketing was without hassle. The motor boat ride to the island was enjoyed by our children of 7 & 5. The island is beautiful. Wearing slippers is advisable as there is dead coral on the beach. We all found the snorkeling experience to be awesome. Our guide was excellent. He took even those of us who couldn't swim and our children deep into the reef. The coral & fish (including a reef shark) was like a real life Discovery Channel!

It's a really great place to speak the day and go snorkeling. The kids loved the snorkeling too. One can get a guide there and they are very helpful. My youngest is 5 years old and he was able to take a float and snorkel. A boat ride there doesn't cost much and if you haven't got gear you can rent it. Would love to go there again.

We visited this island by Boat from our Hotel at Uppuveli. There was a guide to take us fir Snorkling from the Hotel. The Beach is one of the cleanest ones with pure white sand and deep blue sea. This is one of the best spots for snorking where wide variety of fish, sharks and Corals are available. A typical, Tropical paradise of colors inside the water.
This an amazing place to visit. It's crystal clear water and beautiful natural surroundings makes to relax.

We organised a trip to Pigeon Island through our hotel from Coconut Beach Lodges for 3,500 rupees. Price included the boat, entry to Pigeon Island ($10), snorkels and flippers (make sure you try the flippers on to ensure they aren't broken), bananas and water. We spent 2 hours snorkeling around the island and saw turtles, a couple of reef sharks and lots of beautiful fish. The coral is sadly not in great condition. Our boat driver minded our belongings on the beach but there are no secure areas so maybe don't bring money or valuables just to be sure. We really enjoyed the trip and it definitely wasn't as busy as we were expecting it to be. We snorkeled around the side of the island and were the only ones there. Definitely worth a visit.

Going to pigeon island is a great half day trip! We paid 3500 rupees per person - started at 8:45 at uppeveli beach to get our snorkels and flippers then it's a 30 minute boat ride out to the island. You are provided water and biscuits/bananas by the company. Once there, there are two sites that they recommend you snorkel in though technically you could probably snorkel around the whole island. Underwater it is really beautiful and we saw so many fish, reef sharks and two turtles! Unfortunately there is a lot of dead coral as you swim around however there didn't seem to be the hoards of tourists as described in previous reviews. It would have been nice to get a bit longer on the island, we had two hours in the water then spent around half an hour taking photos on the rope swings. Overall a great activity to do!
The entire family enjoyed the visit. No food or beverages available at the park. Great experience for everyone. But I feel no proper attention is given to preserve the corals.

Got to see a few turtles, sharks and heaps of coral fish... it cost us 10,000lkr for two people which included tickets to the national park, boat ride,snorkelling equipment and guide. Worth the visit ...

I am torn because it is a stunning area to snorkel, right off the Nilaveli beach. I swam all around the Pigeon island (possible if you want to take your time and are a decent swimmer) and saw many coral reef sharks and spent a lot of time alone with a couple hawksbill sea turtles, as well as a lot of other fish and coral. But they are starting to build a jetty on the island which will destroy the whole ecosystem as well as the livelihood of the many people living off of tourism to the island. The coral is already not in the best shape it's ever been in, but having this many boats coming and going to the island will truly destroy all the marine life that still exists there.

Pigeon island was a 45 minute boat ride away from the main beach. The island was busy that morning with the hustle and bustle of many other tourists but only a short walk and our guide took us to a quitter more serene spot on the island. The snorkelling experience was absolutely enjoyable and a few unexpected surprises from the sea like turtles and white tip sharks swimming along side us. We sure didn't expect them to be this close. After like an hour at this spot we went to the other side of the island for some more snorkelling where the water is a bit deeper and the collection of coral and fish was more vibrant and colourful. We definitely recommend a visit to this island.

This is a paradise.. TBH didn't see a single Pigeon. lol We did snorkeling in both sided in the island.. it was fantastic.... saw lots of fishes, couple of Turtles one white fin shark.  Beware of jelly fish if they touch your sking get itchy. this is a very beautiful place ..but need to look after more. As people stand on the corals they are dying ....also poor management... it will die soon if tourists ( both local and Foreign) and responsible persons not look after this properly.

It's coral reef offers with rich marine life, colorful fish & virgin corals. If you are a good swimmer you might get lucky to spot reef sharks as well. There is no shade in the Island. Snorkeling trips could be arranged on the spot. Only six people can go in a boat.

an ok experience if you want to out of a nice experience. Coral nothing special, fish the same. If you're very lucky you might see a reef-shark or water tortoise. watch out, prices vary a lot. Hotels will ask up to RS 12.000, yet Rs 7500-8000 is a reasonable price including hired gear and transport.
Pigeon island is a nice place to do snorkeling. After 15 minutes boat you wil discover ocean life : turtles, shark. Take care it can be crowded. It is better early in the morning.

If you have never snorkelled before, then this could work for you but lower your expectations. The boat trip is only 10 min, a little bouncy but not too bad. My wife was 5.5 months pregnant and she had no issues (besides a bouncing baby). Visibility is mediocre at best, apparently we are in off-season (Tip: mind you they didn't tell us that when we paid 7,900 rupees for two pax.) Most of the coral has been damaged from the Tsunami, and PRCs trampling on the coral... very sad to see. Highlight of the snorkel was seeing 5 black tip reef sharks, some of them up to 4 feet. We didn't see turtles but apparently there was a few swimming around. We did see barracudas, parrot fish and small schools of fish but nothing great. If I had my time again, I would have put the 80 bucks towards something else...

Pigeon island has two amazingg snorkel spots that you can snorkel at, at your own pace. One is a reef that has a lot of beautiful tropical fish and it's pretty shallow. Another is the coral bed where you can find turtles and black tip reef sharks and a few fish too. I really miss this place and I would love to go back. Make sure you haggle/look for a good price for the pigeon island trip. (The price I finally found was 3500 Lankan rupees) Please don't carry and dump plastic on the beautiful island!! It will kill the inhabitants!!

This is one of 2 ocean national parks in Sri Lanka (the other one is in Hikkaduwa). It is an excellent place to snorkel and see a variety of fish. We were even able to see Turtles and Sharks. Unfortunately, people do not respect the coral and the environment. The beach is covered with broken coral. :(

I had visited this island in July 1980 and thought the snorkelling to be excellent. July is in the 'correct ' season for snorkelling on this coast. I knew that it was a longshot going in January and was correct. You can only snorkel off the western side of the island at this time of the year. The coral is dead for some considerable distance offshore and the water a little murky. Far too many people go out to this island as it is one of the only snorkelling places around this area.

fairly unspoilt island - 20 minutes there over waves - good snorkelling - very shallow over coral.  Need to be careful getting in and out.  Also watch out for chinese tourists smashing the place up - may not be in such good nick for long.

We stayed at this wonderful small boutique hotel for a couple of nights on our recent visit to Trincomalee. The beach location is perfect vacationing spot. The rooms are quite spacious .From the balcony of any room, you can view beautiful Sandy Beach and its tranquil Indian Ocean waves. There is only one restaurant in the facility and the food is quite basic. All the dishes are well made and taste quite delicious. The bathroom is clean and large with plenty of hot water; the shower is within a large tub. The rain shower was quite high . Overall, our stay was quite magical. I don‚Äôt think I have been to a more beautiful hotel where the beach is only two minutes from your room. I would go back in a heartbeat.

good place for a beach lover and keep in mind if the sea is rough boat riders wont take you there. so before you go its better to check the weather forcast :) . nice beach correls and you can do snookling to

We had a day of snorkeling at pigeon island and it was a highlight of the whole holiday! Our very knowledgeable tour guide was able to show us sea turtle, reef shark and beautiful live coral within 5 minutes of jumping in the water!  Just find a tour that will take you over early, as it gets too busy as the day goes on.

Pigeon island is situated near Nilavely beach and could get boats from Nilavely area. Boats could arrange for group with life jackets. We could reach the pigeon island within 15 to 20 minutes by speed boats. Boat riding are very fun. We could go for coral snoring with trained persons with small payment. They will provide googles and breathing tubes. Remind that be careful while swimming as many big coral are emerges as stone and it all hurt you, otherwise it was very fun and enjoyable. You will get new experience.

This beach area is several km away from Trincomalee. you have to go there only for diving. You will wonder about the nature how this beauty goes under water? pleace dot remove your googles, though it feel breath less beauty! just go for diving

A lovely small island that is about a 15 minute boat trip from the mainland beach. The island will generally become overcrowded by lunchtime as only a small area in the centre of the island is accessible. The seaward facing beach is best for snokling there are a few fish to see.  The landward facing beach only has a small entry/exit channel which is shallow and hemmed in by coral and could be slightly hazardous in even a slight swell. There aren't any facilities on the island so at the very least take some water.  Worth a two hour visit.

Need to see place. If you like diving snorkling... this is the place to be. Beautiful  fish swiming with you, the white sharks just below you amongst the most amazing colourful corals.... makes you feel like your in another world.. best to take the boats off the beach of Nilaveli.. the further away the higher they will charge for the boat ride to the island. Unless you want to go on the ride... üëç
Loved the boat ride to Pigeon Island. Great place for snorkeling and swimming. Loved every second we stayed in the island.

This is a very tiny island. Good for snorkeling. Not much to see. You cannot go for a hike or walk in the bush to see the pigeon. If the department of environment protection and improve the location it would be a better place to be at least to creat a tracking around the island. My recommendation would be go for snorkeling and the tour the island by boat.
A beautiful island with nice corals for snorkelling. I spotted two turtles from very close. If lucky you might be able to see a black tip shark.
This island is amazing for snorkeling around. We saw a good variety of fishes around the island including some small sharks. The corals are good. Amazing experience.

This is the third time I have visited this paradise island. One of the best place for snorkelling in Sri Lanka. There are many variety of tropical colour fishes, sea turtles and even sharks. There is a small path to access some part of the island where you will discover marvellous corals, rocks and some beautiful star fishes. Highly recommanded place for young adult and children. The officials are working hard to implement ecotourism but still there is a lot of plastics bags remaining around the island.

It was absolutely beautiful experience to swim with the shark and watch colourful fish. They charge around LKR 2000 per person and 2000 per boat. Though it was worth the experience, they can spend a little bit of that money in protecting the coral, by educating the tourists and employing staff for that purpose.

We only stayed for two hours, but could have stayed for much longer. There are many nice corals although now in not the greatest shape, but we've seen at least 10 sharks and a couple of turtles. It was an experience of a lifetime for us! We payed about 3000 entrance fee and 2000 for a boat. Worth every penny. We snorkeled only on the western part of the island, the shallow part on the other side was overcrowded.

I am scared of swimming in the sea because of sharks but I ended up snorkeling with them! Absolutely marvelous. The variety of fish is huge and I even saw a big sea turtle. This was the best experience I had and it's a must for everyone.

Snorkling at Pigeon Island was a fun-filled and amazing experience. I could have spent a lot longer than three hours swimming around and viewing the amazing fish and coral in their natural habitat. We also saw lots of reef sharks and a turtle which are both common residents of the  island. I would advise for people to spend a whole day there  if possible and take a picnic - there are plently of table and chairs and shade to spend the entire day. It was beautiful

Yes it's beautiful, but when you arrived you instantly knew that this place is destroyed because of all the tourism. it's sad to see the "guides" stepping on the last living corals. and it's sad to se the lak of respect for nature. We did not see any turtles but som fish and a shark. it was in October and the season is pretty much over but stil many tourists. If you have the opportunity to snorkel at coral garden I would highly recommend that instead

This is a small island just off the coast, easily seen from the beach. It has a small path to explore around and worth the little walk. We used it between dives, and while diving visibility was lousy it was great here. We saw turtles and even a couple of friendly sharks along with lots of fish and an eel. Take shoes as to coral on the beach is sharp.

Beautiful place for snorkelling. Good also for children. Trip from Nilaveli beach not too far. We did not see any turtles, but a shark and lots of colourful fish. They are trying to protect the corals in some areas.
One of the most beautiful places in srilanka ,everyone is very friendly n cooperative you see corals even if you cant swim its safe n everything is done professionally

This is a great snorkelling spot! We didn't have to go far to see turtles and reef sharks which apparently aren't aggressive to humans! It is a bit pricey to get there but well worth it.I was disappointed that I didn't explore the other side of the Island more but was put off by the number of swimmers there.I later found out that the snorkelling was fabulous just going past where Ost of e swimmers are.Talk to the Park warden.He will give you the tips.

this is the third  time i came to this island for snorkelling, cost is about rs 3500 per person for the boat ride to the island. one side of the island is full of beautiful tropical fish, and the other side has the shark and turtle. :-)
We didn't plan to do snorkelling, but it was very nice, although quotes expensive. We saw many sharks and a turtle. It is a pity  that they don't take much care of the coral.

I've never really snorkelled anywhere special before so this was a brilliant experience seeing all the fish and coral in the clear water. By far the highlight was swimming with sharks literally 2m away from me. Took me by a SLIGHT surprise as I hadn't been told, however I now know they were completely safe reef sharks. Still incredible to do though. Don't take too much, you leave your bag just out in the open, but we had no problems.

tldr: Most dead, some tourists are idiots, the government has to step in! This is a tough one. We are almost as guilty as anyone else who keeps on going to this place to add to the destruction. First things first. You can get there either by a tour operator anywhere on a surrounding beach. Tickets to the park cost 2300, gear and boat depends on how you negotiate .. but you can also get all in price of 3500 (standard) and perhaps 3000 if you are good. Per person, of course. Visibility was acceptable. It is not so polluted (at least I did not see it), as some make it to be. The boats all come through a (by now) corral free corridor and land on the beach. You go snorkeling from there and walk a few meters across the island to the second spot. The first is where you will see sharks. I saw at least a dozen. Plus some other fish. Sometimes also turtles, but I did not see them. There are a few living corrals still left, but not many. Some area is behind a line and I think you are not supposed to go in there. Some corrals are still alive behind the line and the water is really shallow ... so if you are not very careful you could damage the few remaining corrals. Unfortunately, this is neither told us nor enforced or anything. So we saw many people swim in there, some literally standing up in the shallow water, probably standing on top of the corrals. This is heartbreaking and makes me very angry. And also feel guilty for fueling this industry myself. On the other side of the island, there are hardly any corrals left. You'll see more fish (and more colorful as well) ... and some big corrals that are not really that colorful ... but that is it. So not sure what the point is. I think if you want to see some more you have to swim around the island .. but since the whole trip is just 2 hours on the island, you do not have the time for that (plus, after 2 hours you cool out). So, would I do it again? No! I have seen it and I am sure there are other areas with nicer corrals that are actually preserved. The visit left me with mixed feelings. I mean, I saw sharks and lots of interesting fish .... and some live corrals ... but many dead ones, stupid people behaving like idiots and no one who cared about that. For the money the government makes here, they should protect the island much better. If you made it till here, thanks for reading I hope I was helpful to your decision making.

We organised a boat to take us to Pigeon Island for a few hours to snorkel, swim etc. Beautiful surrounds and really nice variety of fish and coral. Water can be a tad bit cloudy but that could have been when we travelled. We even saw some reef sharks (safe) and turtles. Beach is full of coral shells. Worth a visit for sure.

Good experience, we saw one turtle, two sharks and a lot of other fishes. The beach is small, covered by corals and full of foreign people. in my mind i thought the island was bigger and i was a little disappointed at first. i think there are better places for snorkeling but in the end it was a nice experience for a half day (almost everyone knows someone that can take you there and since it is a place for tourists only, there's no chance to pay the transport less)

One of the must go places in Trincomalee. The Island is surrounded with a pristine beach and its a great area for diving and snorkeling. Its located about 2.2km off Nilaveli Beach. (The boat ride from the beach to the Island takes about 10 minutes).

It was my first snorkelling experience. I loved it. Saw lots of fishes. Although the water wasn't purely clear, as for me. I saw many small sharks as well. The ticket and boat with mask set rent for two persons costed 60 usd. We visited 25 September 2016. We came around 10.00 am and by 12 it was too crowded and we left. There are no lockers, to keep your bags safely. So, better not to take smth costy or too much money. There are no changing rooms, no washrooms. Just a wild island. So far, it worthy to come and see. But better to stay in Trincomalee, as in Nilaveli is really boring. No place to go.

Nice island apart from the crowds. Not too bad for a quick visit but way too many people there when I visited. The beach at the getting off point is made up of broken coral so you will need shoes or flip flops at a minimum otherwise you will rip your feet to shreds. The snorkelling is excellent if you are into it, watch out for the black tip reef sharks, a thrill to see them. The big shame of the place is watching the tourists especially the Chinese, walking all-over and seriously damaging the coral. A lot more could be done with the place especially in restricting numbers accessing the island.

We decided to do some whale watching, Dolphin sighting, before taking up snorkelling. While coming back to Nilaveli we decided to visit Pigeon Island. With great expectations, However it looked all similar with no much difference, There is fee to pay to visit the island, however the value for money isn't worth the price you pay. It's like paying for a brand name than for the value it adds
Crowded but do not let that put you off, once you are snorkelling the ocean is yours ! lots of living coral and colourful fish.

The Beach is so beautiful!!! We started our ride from Nilaveli Beach and we were taken in a boat to the island and it was a wonderful ride. The island is providing few other activities such as snorkeling. There is a separate place to bathe and for people who come to visit the island,you have to walk in a middle of a small forest I should say, it's refreshing being a small island,basically just like hiking!!!! There is one spot with crystal clear water which is so cool and awesome, it's a real beauty I should say. There is one point in this island where you have to climb on top of a rock where you can get a marvelous view of the ocean and beyond!

Just minutes away from our BNB we took a stroll down the beach and found a sign board promoting Pigeon Island which had boasted snorkeling and lush greenery - we decided to make a day out of it and booked a boat and rented snorkeling gear. As it was my bf first time to snorkel we took a short crash course and learnt more about the island.  The instructor told us stories about the island and of course the dangers of the reef too - he advised us to be wary of sharks as many lived around the island. Off we go in our little boat, took a short tour of the Island and quickly got back into the sea to admire the reef. The reef was grey but was spotted with colorful fish dancing in unison with the tide. I had spotted a giant turtle and followed it to be able to touch it.  The turtle was easy to touch and did not swim away in fear, little did I know that there was a family of bow tie sharks out for their stroll.  Naturally I freaked out and looked in all directions for cover, huge fail as I had followed the turtle into open water away from the reef.  Instinctively I stayed still and let them swim past instead which I am now glad I did.  It was so magical watching them swim past - they didn't mind my ignorance and took their time.  At least 1.2m in length I watched in awe of their movements.  An awesome experience!

Our family did not had any experience in snorkeling. But when we visited this place we were astonished by the beauty of the sea. Such a great experience for me. What a place. Excellent place to visit. Even paying considerable amount of money we should have this experience. Look to go back there.
Lovely snorkeling, had so much fun. It's nice if you go between 9-12 noon. Weather is nice not too hot.

A sad example of too much tourism. It will probably not exist in 20 years. A lot of the coral is dead. There are some fish. There is no attempt to control tourists behaviour or to protect the coral. I saw a shark and a turtle but this place just made me feel sad. Don't bother if you care about the environment.

Sadly - this national park is about to be destroyed. There's no headcount on how many boats and people land on its beach. The coral is dead. The snorkeling areas are crowded - high risk of getting hurt by other smirk lets or people who cannot swim and use floating devices. Most people stand on the corals - others collect bags full of dead corals (for which purpose we are not sure) - a lot of rubbish in the water and due to the human mass sliding into the ocean at once - visibility is very low. We were shocked at the behavior of tourist and lack of engagement of the local wildlife Rangers. The underwater world is beautiful but not for much longer if Sri Lanka keeps ruining national parks just to make some quick bucks. It hurts to see this place!

If it is windy in Trincomalee then I would avoid heading to Pigeon island. September winds are not at all ideal for snorkelling. Our visibility was limited due to the choppy waves and while there may well have been sharks they were just to hard to see.  We did see a couple of turtles but to get to see them requires some pretty strong swimming in less than ideal conditions. The more sheltered side of the island is Ok but the coral is getting trampled and the fish life not particularly prolific.  There were so many people standing on the coral - grr. I am sure the experience could have been better but strong winds causing choppy water are just not ideal.  Pick a day that is calm.

this is a lovely snorkeling spot just a short boat ride from the beach.  there is a park fee, and a boat fee, and snorkeling gear can be rented right there as well (and pretty cheap).  it seems crowded when you first get to the island, but if you are a confident swimmer and love to snorkel, it's easy to get away from the crowd to see some lovely reef, abundant fishes, anemone and even sharks.  it's hot, and the sun is relentless, so look for a spot in the shade to put your towel. It would be nicer if there were some regulations to prevent unskilled swimmers from standing on the reef, but all in all it's a lovely spot.  enough shallow areas for kids to be ok too.

We went for some snorkeling in august 2015 If you like some adventure and swim with black tip sharks it's the right spot. We saw plenty of baby sharks swimming around the beach and bigger one around the corals. We also saw a turtle =) . The negative point is that it's overcrowded and many tourist just walk on the corals destroying them..

If you are going to beaches in eastern Sri Lanka this is one of the best place to do snorkelling, specially if you are adventures. Its a 10-15 minutes boat ride from the mainland and the area is usually full of visitors. Once you get into the water you will realise why. If you can swim you will be able to go to the deep side and swim with sharks (harmless) and turtles.
Incredible sites, I've been once before but the revisit was definitely worth it. Some truly amazing sea life worth going early in the morning before the sea becomes too rough and murky.

Definitely worth visit. Guide will show you where to go (maybe better ask if it is possible before). We saw a giant turtle and also small sharks. What an adrenaline experience as I did not expect that and was swimming alone that moment :D Also nice corals and lots of small colourful fishes. As I wear glasses I didn't expect to anything but the opposite was true, it is not very deep so I saw a lot :)
A bit crowded in the morning, better in the afternoon. Quite expensive but the BBQ was delicious anf fresh
The water is very clear and there are a lot of colourful fishes at the reefs. We saw reef sharks, parrot fish, clownfish, puffer fish etc. A definite must-go if you are in trincomalee!

Amazing place if you like snorkelling. Unfortunately, the island is small and the main beach is quite crowded but you can avoid it just going to the right of where the boat will leave you. The sea can be rough sometimes, better go early or late, but you can watch small sharks and, more interesting, sea turtles.
