My only concern was watching in the main beach people with no swimming skills wearing all fins and destroying the coral. For such a small swim, they don't need fins. They should be forbidden.

Of course there aren't any waves at the island, it's coral reef offers a rich marine life with colorful fish & corals. And of course if you are a good swimmer you might get lucky to spot reef sharks as well. Snorkeling & diving trips could be arranged on the spot. A boat accommodates only seven people young or adults per trip.

After reading mixed reviews, we decided to give Pigeon Island a go and were glad we went. Be aware that people have trodden on the reef close to shore and it is sadly damaged. If you swim further out (and keep your feet/flippers off the reef!) there are some really beautiful fish and coral to view, without leaving a mark. We even spotted the famous reef sharks on the side near where the boats pull in. It cost about $30AUD each which included boat ride from Uppaveli, all snorkelling gear, and entry to the national park. Managed to get in before the masses, and had a really great time!
It's remembering fantasy life in our childhood,paradise to stayacation,best place to snorkeling and feel the sea breeze

This was definitely the high point of our trip to Sri Lanka this year. Initially, we were turned off by the huge park entrance fees and the boat fees one has to pay to get there (a total of 6600 LKR for 2 people!) and having seen very many good snorkeling places in Malaysia, we felt this was quite over-priced. But the snorkeling in Pigeon Island is *really* quite awesome. It's not the best in the world but definitely worth the price you're paying for, and definitely the best you'll get to do in east coast Sri Lanka. (we didn't do any in the west coast, so cant comment). We saw lovely varieties of finger corals, plate coras, brain corals and sponges and were completely mesmerized with the shark and turtle sightings (got a chance to get really close to both these creatures). We saw huge schools of sergentfish, lots of butterflyfishes, trumpetfishes, crown of thorn starfish, lots of parrotfishes, travallys and boxfishes. Definitely as much variety as you get to see in some of the best snorkeling spots in the world. The sharks and turtles will completely make your day. Go there with at least 3 hours of snorkeling time in hand and do NOT return till you see them up close. Go with your own snorkeling equipment and avoid paying the unnecesary 600 bux they'll charge you for snorkeling glasses. Be friendly to the reefs - they're quite shallow in the north-western (rocky) tip of the island, and you may end up damaging some of the corals if you swim too hard. The corals here are beautiful. Protect them!
Maybe I've been to a better place to go snorkeling so I considered Pigeon Island not so special. Besides, travelers need to spend money on the boat-ride and entrance fee for the national park.
Great place to go, the earlier the better,as it does get busy,we did a dolphin watching trip and tied it in with snorkelling on Pidgeon Island.

This place is perfect for seeing many kinds of colorful fish, turtles and black tip sharks although you have to come in the morning for this privilege. However, it's sad to see coral reef in its current state. Limiting the number of visitors would be very welcoming. Make sure you don't go with any agencies. The entrance fee is 2200 rupees per person, fee per boat should not exceed 2000 rupees and day's use of snorkeling gear should not surpass 500 rupees. Find the fishermen on Nilaveli beach and haggle.

This was my first time trying snorkelling, and wow, what a place to try something new! The variety of fish was exceptional - so beautiful and they come very close so you get to enjoy the striking colours and patterns. We saw Angel fish, parrot fish and many wonderful others I couldn't name. We paid approx. ¬£25 for the journey plus ¬£3-¬£4 to hire snorkelling masks and fins. Worth every penny. Take plenty to drink with you as there are no facilities over there and make sure you wear sunscreen all down your back/legs since you'll spend the majority of time floating on your tummy. This visit has been a highlight of my trip so far. Don't miss it! :)

pigeon Island is one and only marine National park in Sri Lanka. suitable for family to do the snorkeling . at least you need half a day to explore under water world.. best time of the Year is June to September...

Quite expensive to get there : admission ticket 2800 (per person), boat 2000. We arrived at 9 in the morning. There were 20ppl. When we left at 1pm there were >200ppl. Coral close to the beach dead or destroyed. Further in the sea good coral, lot of "Nemo" fishes :). We also spotted a 2m shark! Personally i hope they will close this island, to give room to nature again!
This is a great place to relax and go snorkeling. Probably among the best. Please leave only your footsteps if you go there.

Most untouched beach by humans .. Unfortunately people are not mindful to protect it. Lovely corals and water nice and warm , need to ware beach shoes to prevent getting cuts by dead coral pieces. Diving is permitted . Again when you visit take good care of it as we need to protect it for our kids.
Too expensive, too dirty, too crowded. If you pay the ridiculous tourist prices 25 usd pp, at least they should clean up the place!

First of all, DONT PAY more then 3000 per person ( that's how much we paid ) even that is to much, I'm getting tired of them overpricing everything in Uppuveli... People here have to start bargaining... So back to the island, the island is nice looking but there is to many people, so me and my girl decided to swim around the whole island, it took about 1,5 hours and this way your going to be alone, cause 99% of people swim in the designated swimming area. Which is boring cause then your just mostly going to see other humans in the water... Saw a bigger shark when we were swimming alone :) and a lot of other fishes, a small octopus as well!

I have always been a big fan of snorkelling and one place I have always wanted to visit is Pigeon Island National Park - Sri Lanka. My first trip was in 2010 then 2012 and the third in 2016. I have done dives in Maldives, Australia and South Africa but this place is special. The main reason is that I don't need to go into the deep see to be amazed by the beauty of the ocean, even if I dive for 3m your guaranteed that you see the great coral reef and different fish even small sharks. I think it is best if you can have a tracker from the ticket counter or seek advice from them as to where they have seen turtles, sharks or different fish. The guys are extremely knowledgeable and always wanting to help out. The ride to the Island: - You can hire your own speed boat for as little as $20 USD, from Marble Beach (Return trip) Remeber you only pay when you come back to Marble Beach. There is no time limit so you can even spend the whole day the island. (Up to 5 guests) - Then the admission costs would be $40 or $5 USD depending whether your local or not. MUST NOTE: - There are no toilets or any other changing facilities in the Island so you need to be prepared. Deep sea diving you would need to organise it with special diving licenced boats and they will range from $40.00 - $60.00 USD depending what you want to see and how deep you want to dive. Season : April 2nd week to Last week June. Try it out, it will be one of the best places you will see on earth.

Probably one of the best places in the whole of Sri Lanka. This is the second time I visited and snorkeled around. Absoltely beautiful coral reefs and marine life to explore.Make sure snorkel on the side where the boats stop. We managed to see a lobster, many beautiful fish and to cap things off sharks (6ft). The sharks were totally harmless and swam around minding there own business, Also dont forget to go the partially completed observation deck at the top, which offers some great views.
A day trip here is a great experience with helpful guides who just seem to love what they do. We had a very enjoyable trip. Tip - snorkelling gear can be hired, but best to take your own

A speed bot ride from Nilaveli beach takes you to Pigeon Island. Known for its rich and abundant coral reefs, a nice dive at the beach and some snorkeling makes you feel like you are swimming with the fishes. A must visit if you go to Nilaveli beach or Trincomalee.

A must place to go if you spend time near trincomalee! You wont find better spots to do snorkeling in Sri Lanka than this! The island was though quite crouded which made the experience a bit unpleasant. But we saw many nice fish and even a couple of reef sharks and an octopus. It is clearly worth visiting but keep in mind that Sri Lanka does not offer the best under water experience in Asia

The reef has some obvious signs of wear and tear from visitors and could probably do with having fewer visitors, but there are some pretty corals, brightly coloured fish and sharks. Remember to snorkel both sides of the island. Cheap trips can be done if you team up, go to the ticket office opposite the island and haggle. Going via other companies will often add 50-100% to your price for the same service. Nice morning activity.
One of the most beautiful places in Sri Lanka especially for people who love swimming, snorkelling and just want to have good time!

Had a really good time snorkling here during a resting period between dives. Managed to see some great corals, beautiful fish and the black tipped reef sharks. Not sure if it is worth going here just for the snorkling here though, would recommend diving as well because of the entrance fee of 15 dollars.

well protected coral reef under srilanka navy. there are two sides of the island. the side you arrive is good for snorkeling and not allowed to walk on the reef. which is extremely good and they will blow a whistle if you do so, you can see small sharks about 4-5 ft who are used to tourists. no harm at all. its an amazing place that makes you foget about the time. the best time to go is early morning, and about 1-2 pm due to low tide some parts of reef come above sea level. the other side is a bay, lots of locals will be there if it is a holiday. and if you go bit further on that side bit deep and lot of rocks. there is a nature trail but snorkeling will forget you everything best period to visit is May to October

The island is an interesting place to visit but unfortunately far too many people are using a very small snorkeling area and as a consequence destroying the coral reef and the earlier in day you go there the less people, the less disturbance. I snorkeled out and saw some reef life but nearer the island the reef is dying. There is little in the way of amenities there but we found the wildlife rangers very helpful and informative. I hired snorkeling equipment and after an hour managed to obtain the flippers - however the snorkeling equipment was brand new and had a reasonable hire price even for foreigners. As is the case in Sri Lanka, foreigners pay more than the locals, but in many cases 20+ times for attractions that really not worth the excess charge.  Often it is not the amount but the way charges increases during the visit to an attraction. We know that there are scams - when we went to get the tickets for entry onto Pigeon Island no papers changed hands!  When we asked for a ticket /receipt we were told that our boatman had given the tickets to another boatman and he had lost them when they blew into the sea.  Eventually, our Sri Lankan friends managed to get the foreigner tickets but not the 6 local tickets from a very  sullen boatman. We have visited Sri Lanka on six occasions to stay our friends and have noted the situation getting worse. As soon as a foreigner is seen the price goes up even if the original price is marked on the item.  I am not sure if Sri Lankan's understand business let alone the tourist industry - every tourist I've met there has had similar experiences

Amazing snorkeling experience.  Very good. Easy to get to from Nilaveli beach. Easy to find boat operator's and it cost around  Rs 2000 for boat trip (6 people) to island and back. Boat trip is very short. You can organise a guide if you want for extra cost. You need to buy tickets for the island prior to leaving for the island. Ticket prices reduce in cost the more you have in your group. You can hire snorkeling gear from boat operator's Rs 650 per set. Pigeon island worth doing if you visit Trincomalee.

We were brought to the pigeon island as part of dive trip. It is a beautiful island with a lot of tourists who enjoy some snorkling here. Was told there were black tip sharks and turtles but I personally didn't see any. Would recommend to go and have a look!

I hated the pigeon island trip. The coral was dead from too many people walking on it, there was rubbish everywhere and far too many people. Unfortunately this whole area felt like development and tourism gone very wrong, and a beautiful place has already been ruined. Such a shame, as well regulated it could be stunning but I'm afraid it's already too late.

No doubt the island and the snorkling is nice. We even saw some sharks. If you swim a little bit further away from the shore the reef isn't as destroyed as in the main zone. Compared to other places it's not outstanding. It's a good idea to go as Early as possible. Midday it's getting crowded. Now pricing: We paid 4700 Rs for the island. They told us boat trip is included. After we went back we were forced to pay another 2000 Rs for the boat trip. Ok, as expected they try to rip you off! We stayed in trinco with a tamil family and they told us for locals it's 100 Rs only. This kind of difference is what bothers me a lil. I knew that tourists pay more but unfortunately it seems to getting out of hands in sri lanka. Furthermore, the whole negotiating about prices is exhausting. Hopefully they won't scare too many tourists off with this behaviour, but if they continue this way I am not so sure about that...

Many diving and snorkeling operators organize trip to Pigeon Island, which is part of Sri Lanka's national park. If you're lucky you can spot blacktip shark swimming near the shallow coral reef on the island.

Besided ridicilous high prices, the snorkling is nothing special compared to elsewhere in asia. Coral died, people step on it. The two small snorkling areas and couple of benches are packed with tourists. One plus: you can actually see some small sharks or turtles around the island but then you need a good guide. I recommend aqua dreams. However, in general i found the island experience overrated and overpriced....

Pigeon Island is consists of two islands, one is small and other one is larger in size. This is one of the paramount places to see corals.  Pigeon Island, a little rocky island where the blue Rock pigeons variety, and whose waters around are a delight of colorful fishes. Popular with tourists, the island can be reached by boats hired from any of the hotels or from the beach. In year 2003 Pigeon Island was nominated as a nation park in Sri Lanka earlier it was a place of safety.

Fantastic snorkelling, thousands of fish, sharks and turtles Coral is good, saw types I've never seen before. Quite strong rips, definitely wear flippers, and if you're not a strong swimmer wear a life jacket Lots of shade under the trees if you just want to go and watch.

There are plenty of beautiful fish to see around Pigeon Island. The coral is certainly more bleached than not. Try getting there early - 8am - to avoid the crowds. Unfortunately the snorkelling isn't well policed, a lot of people were treading on the corals or littering. Nilaveli co-op boats is the cheapest way to get there, the more people in your group the cheaper.
Gorgeous place where you are sure to swim with wonderful species. Arrive early, before other boats loaded with people

We had a wonderful day snorkelling despite the wind and overcast weather. It's a lovely shallow reef right of the beach which made it safe and enjoyable for the kids. A must do if your in the area! Go early and beat the crowds.

If it is fish you want to see, this is the place. You have to hire a boat for Rs 2500 and a ticket to be purchase to enter the Island. Go with at least bath room sleepers as lot of corrals. The best place to snorkeling.

A gorgeous place to visit, and so glad i made the trip to Pigeon Island, which is just opposite Anilava Nilaveli resort - about a 10 minute boat ride. (all prices in Sri Lankan rupees) The boats are quite expensive - 2000 rupees the national park ticket fee is also expensive to enter - 3000 rupees for one person, or 4,200 rupees for 2 people approx The fish are beautiful and can be seen - though the water clarity was less than i expected.  The water seems fresh and clean, but with natural sediment/waves adding a little bit of cloudiness.  Even still - the corals a little deeper really were incredible - we saw reef sharks (safely!) and gorgeous tropical fish!  Would recommend the experience.  It does get a bit crowded - but in the off season a little further out, the experience was tranquil and unbelievable - to see a whole other world beneath the sea (and I'm from Australia - the land of the Great Barrier Reef!)

We had a lovely experience on the island. It is defnitely sad to see all the dead coral due to bleeching, and uninformed tourist that damage it, but the overall experience was very positive. I heard that there were scientists that were planting some new more resistant coral here, and atleast there are some areas that have been closed off for protection. We really made the most of it, by swimming right around the island...even though we were told it is not possible! It is! Rather exhausting though...took us the full 2,5hrs that we had on the island, but it was totaly worth it, and because of that we were the only people who saw turtles! Also hundrets of reef fish and 3 blacktip reef sharks!! Amazing.

We spent a weekday here and got the boat across from Nilavelli Beach Hotel (our driver assured us this is the cheapest way of getting across - cost 1800 rupees for the boat and the driver came and collected us at a time of our choosing). Cost additional 4700 rupees for 2 of us entry on the island. Had a great day there - swam with black tip reef sharks and saw swathes of tropical fish. There are turtles there too but sadly didn't see these this time. Friendly people there giving advice and telling you to keep away from the eels!! Definitely worth a trip over and Nilavelli beach is also a beautiful spot!

Beautiful if you're in Trincomalee don't miss it!  Make sure that you're going there early morning (9). You should spent there at least 5 hours. Bring with you a lot of water and snacks. Snorkeling can be very exhausting. Enjoy!

Try and head there on weekdays and not the weekends, for less of the local crowd and a more private experience. It's best to bring your own snorkel gear. The corals are dying here, but you do see some marine life. Sunsets here are spectacular.

Fantastic experience swimming with turtles and reef sharks. Unbelievable experience! Coral is damaged but that happened during the tsunami a few years back. Island is pristine and beautiful. I wish I had returned and walked along the island. Hat and SPF is a must! 9 out of 10.

By the time we were contemplating a trip here, we had already visited two national parks in Sri Lanka. So our expectations were very very high and it mat all of them. For most of the first hour of snorkelling, I was repeating the words: ‚ÄúLook, look‚Äù because of I was so mesmerised by the size of the fishes and the colours of the oceans. When we started exploring the corals, it was more muted respect for than words. There is an entire world under the ocean and it is waiting for you. If you don‚Äôt see it, you are missing out on more than you can understand. On a more practical note, I would recommend a guide so that he/she can take you deeper into the ocean.
Entrance fee of 4700 for two people for Pigeon Island. It was a very nice island which was quite busy at the time, even though it's the off season. The snorkeling was great, nice coral and fish.

A must visit for those visiting the Trincomalee or Nilaveli area. Rent a private boat to get to the Island. Wonderful snorkeling opportunity around the reefs. Amongst the beautiful marine life, there are also sharks and turtles. A nice day out with family or friends.

Beautiful islands with great snorkelling opportunities. We went here and managed to see three sharks. It's quite expensive to visit and they say the money goes towards conservation, however There were no projects I could see. The beach was nice and clean and it was refreshing to not see any buildings. Worth a visit

This was a pretty expensive excursion but worth it. We snorkeled for about 2 hours, which was plenty of time for us. You must first buy your entrance tickets on he mainland, then find a boat company (not hard - they kind of grab you) that lends you snorkel gear and takes you out to the island, all for a fee of course. Many parts were beautiful and we really enjoyed it. To note: common sense, but careful with the sun! We used sunscreen and our backs still got burnt to a crisp out there! I'd reapply lotion in between snorkeling each side of the island if I went again.
Very nice attraction! A lot of fishes and very nice corals... There you can find some sharks as well... But not dangerous (never know)... Ideal place for snorkeling...

Hands down the best place (and probably only) to spot reef sharks while diving off Trincomalee. You're almost guaranteed to see atleast one, unless you've got the worst luck in the world. Need to take a boat from Nilaveli after picking up a ticket of some sorts from the Marine Wildlife Department. A boatman called Ashok (office on the beach outside coral Bay hotel) took us there for Rs 3800 each, all inclusive. The boat ride lasts about ten to fifteen minutes. The island has two sides to it that permits snorkeling. The side you land on is for the more advanced swimmer or so they say. This side has clearly defined areas that one can't swim through, but you're free to snorkel everywhere else. The cordoned off area basically consists of live coral that they don't want you damaging. These areas are quite shallow and I didn't want to go in there anyway. The other areas are lovely. Teeming with fish and if you're really lucky turtles. I saw three sharks ambling about quite lazily not two feet from me. I'd definitely recommend snorkelling here. The other side of the island has a much shallower reef. Smaller fish but tons of them. I'd recommend swimming the other side first and then relaxing here. All in all you need between 2 to 3 hours here.

Pigeon Island is located a short boat ride away from Nilaveli beach. You need to get an admission ticket to enter the island and take a boat to get there. For locals, the admission ticket is about Rs. 350 and the return boat ride is Rs. 2000. The island is a very small beautiful one with a short beach and is managed by the navy. There are life guards that will guide you on which areas to snorkel. There's an area in the middle section that is protected and not allowed to enter. The rest can be viewed when you snorkel. The beach near ocean is filled with coral debris and therefore, be careful when you walk. Always wear slippers otherwise it's very difficult to walk on. The moment we entered the ocean we had corals surrounding us. Beautiful and colorful corals look really pretty. but if you want to see the best corals, go around the buoy line.That's where you'll see the turtles, reef sharks, most beautiful fish and breath taking coral gardens. If you're afraid of the deep, ask a lifeguard to take you to the deep areas. They know where turtles and sharks usually are and will make sure you don't miss them. Lifeguard did not charge a fixed amount for taking us. He told to give what we feel like giving which is better than having a high fixed amount. From the moment we got to the island till we left, we had stayed for about 3 hours. Didn't feel the time flying as it was such a mesmerizing experience. We went in mid May and there was a slight rain throughout the day and low sunlight. The corals were still visible but i think it would've looked much better if there was enough sun light. The area people told best time to visit is June. This is a protected island so don't leave any plastic in the island. Whatever you take to the island, make sure you bring it back.

We came to Nilaveli for diving.  The small marine park is not big enough to protect marine life and there were no more fish within the park than there were outside the park where you did not have to pay 2800 LKR (about 20 US$) per person per day.  There are no mooring buoys so the dive boats throw their anchors on the coral.   The area is heavily fished and the coral was only average, disappointing since we came halfway around the world to dive here. The island is very small and very crowded.  There are a couple of resident black tip sharks and a turtle and some impressive stag horn coral in the snorkeling area.  There is also a nature trail.  Overall, it is a successful method to separate tourists from their money.

Good snorkeling when coming off-season. The beach is very small, so might get crowded. You might see a reef shark. The equipment rented on the main shore (before boarding the boat) is of low quality and there are no small-kids sizes, so it is preferred to have your own equipment.

Pigeon Island used to be pristine and truly a place to be (I visited it first in 2010 when my friends and I were the only ones on the island). Having visited it in April 2016, the place is so crowded it has lost its lure. The corals and marine life visible just under the waters surface are stunning but the sheer crowds lead me to question as to how long it will remain pristine. Facilities are almost non-existent except for a hut to buy tickets at upon landing on the island.
We really love this place. We spent more than 5 hours . Had a nice shooting. Nice place to forget ourselves. Don't miss once u get a chance to visit Trincomalee.

Try snorkeling.... You can rent the gear (life jackets and goggles) from the boating people and get a tour guide from the island or snorkel by yourself... It's a great experience even if you don't know how to swim... The sea bed is bit rough with corrals... So better to have some protective swim wear... Must have experience....

what a beautiful spot for snorkeling and diving. Maybe the only downside is the $20 you have to pay as a tourist. The locals only have to pay 40 cents. All up for boat trip etc it cost my wife and me $100 to go snorkeling, worth it if you can afford it.

Swim a mere 10/20 meters from the shore line and you're joined by a swell of beautiful tropical fish of all colours as well as black tipped reef sharks (don't worry they don't bite!) and the majestic turtle! Do not miss this if you're heading near Trincomalee!

The place is beautiful, but the nature is damaged. We saw a lot of Fish, including Sharks.  But the riff and the corals are nearly dead. Too Bad for a beautiful place like that. Price is with government charges but i doubt that the money is used wisely...

This is the best place to do snorkeling in Sri Lanka. Wide variety of corals and fishes are there including sharks.If you're not going to go by a private vehicle there are buses that you can take from tricomalee. It 'll take around 1hour to reach nilaweli. After get off from the bus you to go another 1.2 km to the beach. There are three wheelers if you like to go easily. I recommend you to go there early morning. Make sure you are going there in season. Otherwise the way will be closed. And don't get caught to any people other than coastal guard people of army. Main thing, one boat is allowed to carry only 7 peoples. Please make sure you don't harm to corals in the island. And don't try to bring back any of corals in here. Only leave your footprints there. Try to stay there at least half a day. And make sure you bring plenty of water. If you are going to stay there for a considerable time it'll be good to bring a fully covered swimwear. Because sun will definitely burn your skin to a whole new colour.

Our children saw the first time in here life reef sharks during snorkeling. Some of them are almost 1.40m! Sometimes we spotted several sharks at one moment. Very cool! A problem are some tourists who were walking on the reef. Take care of this paradise! We also spotted a green turtle, many coral fishes and morray eals. In high season (july/august) maybe its bether to avoid this place. It will be overcrowded with tourists!

We spent a whole day there and it wasn't enough. Snorkelling with reef sharks and turtles was increbible and the marine park officers were incredibly helpful taking the younger children (and adults who were afraid to swim) snorkelling. Amazing beach and incredible sminning water.

For the 1st time did snorkelling. You dont have to be a great swimmer to do this. There'll be a life guard accompanying you all the time. A very safe place with presense of police and guards all the time. They don't ripoff tourists. Can rent snorkelling kits for 300 sl rupees. Great experience.

Snorkelling for different abilities with plenty to see - corals, fish, eels, octopus, sharks and much more.  When we visited the swell meant visiting the reef edge was off limits (for us), but no shortage of things to keep us looking in the shallower waters.  One of the national park guides swam with us to make sure we saw things that we might have otherwise missed - great enthusiasm and a genuine love for the place. A good half-day experience - go in the morning rather than the evening.  And look out for the big hermit crabs on the island (which does have many pigeons on it too).
